name: PIXI
description: The [pixi.js](http://www.pixijs.com/) module/namespace.

name: Line
description: Container for line-related functions

name: Point
description: Point related functions

name: Polygon
description: Polygon class.

name: Scalar
description: Scalar functions

name: AABB
description: Axis aligned bounding box class.

name: Broadphase
description: Base class for broadphase implementations.

name: NaiveBroadphase
description: Naive broadphase implementation. Does N^2 tests.

name: Narrowphase
description: Narrowphase. Creates contacts and friction given shapes and transforms.

name: Ray
description: A line with a start and end point that is used to intersect shapes. For an example, see {{#crossLink "World/raycast:method"}}World.raycast{{/crossLink}}

name: RaycastResult
description: Storage for Ray casting hit data.

name: SAPBroadphase
description: Sweep and prune broadphase along one axis.

name: Constraint
description: Base constraint class.

name: DistanceConstraint
description: Constraint that tries to keep the distance between two bodies constant.

params.description: The distance to keep between the anchor points. Defaults to the current distance between the bodies.
params.name: options.distance

params.description: The anchor point for bodyA, defined locally in bodyA frame. Defaults to [0,0].
params.name: options.localAnchorA

params.description: The anchor point for bodyB, defined locally in bodyB frame. Defaults to [0,0].
params.name: options.localAnchorB

params.description: Maximum force to apply.
params.name: options.maxForce

name: GearConstraint
description: Constrains the angle of two bodies to each other to be equal. If a gear ratio is not one, the angle of bodyA must be a multiple of the angle of bodyB.

params.description: Relative angle between the bodies. Will be set to the current angle between the bodies (the gear ratio is accounted for).
params.name: options.angle

params.description: Gear ratio.
params.name: options.ratio

params.description: Maximum torque to apply.
params.name: options.maxTorque

examples:
var constraint = new GearConstraint(bodyA, bodyB);
    world.addConstraint(constraint);

name: LockConstraint
description: Locks the relative position and rotation between two bodies.

params.description: The offset of bodyB in bodyA's frame. If not given the offset is computed from current positions.
params.name: options.localOffsetB

params.description: The angle of bodyB in bodyA's frame. If not given, the angle is computed from current angles.
params.name: options.localAngleB

name: PrismaticConstraint
description: Constraint that only allows bodies to move along a line, relative to each other. See this tutorial. Also called "slider constraint".

params.description: Max force to be applied by the constraint
params.name: options.maxForce

params.description: Body A's anchor point, defined in its own local frame.
params.name: options.localAnchorA

params.description: Body B's anchor point, defined in its own local frame.
params.name: options.localAnchorB

params.description: An axis, defined in body A frame, that body B's anchor point may slide along.
params.name: options.localAxisA

params.description: If set to true, bodyB will be free to rotate around its anchor point.
params.name: options.disableRotationalLock

name: RevoluteConstraint
description: Connects two bodies at given offset points, letting them rotate relative to each other around this point.

params.description: A pivot point given in world coordinates. If specified, localPivotA and localPivotB are automatically computed from this value.
params.name: options.worldPivot

params.description: The point relative to the center of mass of bodyA which bodyA is constrained to.
params.name: options.localPivotA

params.description: See localPivotA.
params.name: options.localPivotB

params.description: The maximum force that should be applied to constrain the bodies.
params.name: options.maxForce

name: AngleLockEquation
description: Locks the relative angle between two bodies. The constraint tries to keep the dot product between two vectors, local in each body, to zero. The local angle in body i is a parameter.

params.description: Angle to add to the local vector in body A.
params.name: options.angle

params.description: Gear ratio
params.name: options.ratio

name: ContactEquation
description: Non-penetration constraint equation. Tries to make the contactPointA and contactPointB vectors coincide, while keeping the applied force repulsive.

name: Equation
description: Base class for constraint equations.

params.description: First body participating in the equation
params.name: bodyA

params.description: Second body participating in the equation
params.name: bodyB

params.description: Minimum force to apply. Default: -Number.MAX_VALUE
params.name: minForce

params.description: Maximum force to apply. Default: Number.MAX_VALUE
params.name: maxForce

name: FrictionEquation
description: Constrains the slipping in a contact along a tangent

name: RotationalLockEquation
description: Locks the relative angle between two bodies. The constraint tries to keep the dot product between two vectors, local in each body, to zero. The local angle in body i is a parameter.

params.description: Angle to add to the local vector in bodyA.
params.name: options.angle

name: RotationalVelocityEquation
description: Syncs rotational velocity of two bodies, or sets a relative velocity (motor).

name: EventEmitter
description: Base class for objects that dispatches events.

name: ContactMaterial
description: Defines what happens when two materials meet, such as what friction coefficient to use. You can also set other things such as restitution, surface velocity and constraint parameters.

params.description: Friction coefficient.
params.name: options.friction

params.description: Restitution coefficient aka "bounciness".
params.name: options.restitution

params.description: ContactEquation stiffness.
params.name: options.stiffness

params.description: ContactEquation relaxation.
params.name: options.relaxation

params.description: FrictionEquation stiffness.
params.name: options.frictionStiffness

params.description: FrictionEquation relaxation.
params.name: options.frictionRelaxation

params.description: Surface velocity.
params.name: options.surfaceVelocity

name: Material
description: Defines a physics material.

params.description: Material identifier
params.name: id

name: vec2
description: The vec2 object from glMatrix, with some extensions and some removed methods. See http://glmatrix.net.

name: Body
description:
A rigid body. Has got a center of mass, position, velocity and a number of
shapes that are used for collisions.

params.description: A number >= 0. If zero, the .type will be set to Body.STATIC.
params.name: options.mass

name: LinearSpring
description:
A spring, connecting two bodies.

The Spring explicitly adds force and angularForce to the bodies.

params.description: A number > 0. Default is the current distance between the world anchor points.
params.name: options.restLength

params.description: Spring constant (see Hookes Law). A number >= 0.
params.name: options.stiffness

params.description: A number >= 0. Default: 1
params.name: options.damping

params.description: Where to hook the spring to body A, in world coordinates. Overrides the option "localAnchorA" if given.
params.name: options.worldAnchorA

params.description: Where to hook the spring to body A, in local body coordinates. Defaults to the body center.
params.name: options.localAnchorA

name: RotationalSpring
description:
A rotational spring, connecting two bodies rotation. This spring explicitly adds angularForce (torque) to the bodies.

The spring can be combined with a {{#crossLink "RevoluteConstraint"}}{{/crossLink}} to make, for example, a mouse trap.

params.description: The relative angle of bodies at which the spring is at rest. If not given, it's set to the current relative angle between the bodies.
params.name: options.restAngle

params.description: Spring constant (see Hookes Law). A number >= 0.
params.name: options.stiffness

params.description: A number >= 0.
params.name: options.damping

name: Spring
description: A spring, connecting two bodies. The Spring explicitly adds force and angularForce to the bodies and does therefore not put load on the constraint solver.

params.description: Spring constant (see Hookes Law). A number >= 0.
params.name: options.stiffness

params.description: A number >= 0. Default: 1
params.name: options.damping

params.description: Where to hook the spring to body A, in local body coordinates. Defaults to the body center.
params.name: options.localAnchorA

params.description: Where to hook the spring to body A, in world coordinates. Overrides the option "localAnchorA" if given.
params.name: options.worldAnchorA

name: TopDownVehicle

params.description: A dynamic body, already added to the world.
params.name: chassisBody

params.description: local wheel forward vector in local body space. Default is zero.
params.name: options.localForwardVector

params.description: The local position of the wheen in the chassis body. Default is zero - the center of the body.
params.name: options.localPosition

params.description: The max friction force in the sideways direction.
params.name: options.sideFriction

name: Box
description: Box shape class.

params.description: (Note that this options object will be passed on to the {{#crossLink "Shape"}}{{/crossLink}} constructor.)
params.name: options

params.description: Total width of the box
params.name: options.width

params.description: Total height of the box
params.name: options.height

name: Capsule
description: Capsule shape class.

params.description: (Note that this options object will be passed on to the {{#crossLink "Shape"}}{{/crossLink}} constructor.)
params.name: options

params.description: The distance between the end points
params.name: options.length

params.description: Radius of the capsule
params.name: options.radius

name: Circle
description: Circle shape class.

params.description: (Note that this options object will be passed on to the {{#crossLink "Shape"}}{{/crossLink}} constructor.)
params.name: options

params.description: The radius of this circle
params.name: options.radius

examples:
var circleShape = new Circle({ radius: 1 });
    body.addShape(circleShape);

name: Convex
description: Convex shape class.

params.description: (Note that this options object will be passed on to the {{#crossLink "Shape"}}{{/crossLink}} constructor.)
params.name: options

params.description: An array of vertices that span this shape. Vertices are given in counter-clockwise (CCW) direction.
params.name: options.vertices

params.description: An array of unit length vectors, representing the symmetry axes in the convex.
params.name: options.axes

name: Heightfield
description: Heightfield shape class. Height data is given as an array. These data points are spread out evenly with a distance "elementWidth".

params.description: (Note that this options object will be passed on to the {{#crossLink "Shape"}}{{/crossLink}} constructor.)
params.name: options

params.description: An array of Y values that will be used to construct the terrain.
params.name: options.heights

params.description: Minimum value of the data points in the data array. Will be computed automatically if not given.
params.name: options.minValue

params.description: Maximum value.
params.name: options.maxValue

params.description: World spacing between the data points in X direction.
params.name: options.elementWidth

name: Line
description: Line shape class. The line shape is along the x direction, and stretches from [-length/2, 0] to [length/2,0].

params.description: (Note that this options object will be passed on to the {{#crossLink "Shape"}}{{/crossLink}} constructor.)
params.name: options

params.description: The total length of the line
params.name: options.length

name: Particle
description: Particle shape class.

params.description: (Note that this options object will be passed on to the {{#crossLink "Shape"}}{{/crossLink}} constructor.)
params.name: options

name: Plane
description: Plane shape class. The plane is facing in the Y direction.

params.description: (Note that this options object will be passed on to the {{#crossLink "Shape"}}{{/crossLink}} constructor.)
params.name: options

name: Shape
description: Base class for shapes.

name: GSSolver
description: Iterative Gauss-Seidel constraint equation solver.

name: Solver
description: Base class for constraint solvers.

name: OverlapKeeper
description: Keeps track of overlaps in the current state and the last step state.

name: OverlapKeeperRecord
description: Overlap data container for the OverlapKeeper

name: Utils
description: Misc utility functions

name: Island
description: An island of bodies connected with equations.

name: IslandManager
description: Splits the system of bodies and equations into independent islands

name: IslandNode
description: Holds a body and keeps track of some additional properties needed for graph traversal.

name: World
description: The dynamics world, where all bodies and constraints live.

params.description: Defaults to GSSolver.
params.name: options.solver

params.description: Defaults to y=-9.78.
params.name: options.gravity

params.description: Defaults to SAPBroadphase
params.name: options.broadphase

name: PIXI
description:
Namespace-class for [pixi.js](http://www.pixijs.com/).

Contains assorted static properties and enumerations.

name: DisplayObject
description:
The base class for all objects that are rendered on the screen.
This is an abstract class and should not be used on its own rather it should be extended.

name: DisplayObjectContainer
description:
A DisplayObjectContainer represents a collection of display objects.
It is the base class of all display objects that act as a container for other objects.

name: Sprite
description: The Sprite object is the base for all textured objects that are rendered to the screen

params.name: texture

name: SpriteBatch
Stage
description: A Stage represents the root of the display tree. Everything connected to the stage is rendered

params.description:
the background color of the stage, you have to pass this in is in hex format
     like: 0xFFFFFF for white

Creating a stage is a mandatory process when you use Pixi, which is as simple as this :
var stage = new PIXI.Stage(0xFFFFFF);
where the parameter given is the background colour of the stage, in hex
you will use this stage instance to add your sprites to it and therefore to the renderer
Here is how to add a sprite to the stage :
stage.addChild(sprite);
params.name: backgroundColor

name: PolyK

params.description: the current WebGL drawing context
params.name: gl

params.description: the current WebGL drawing context
params.name: gl

params.description: the current WebGL drawing context
params.name: gl

params.description: the current WebGL drawing context
params.name: gl

params.description: the current WebGL drawing context
params.name: gl

name: WebGLGraphics
description: A set of functions used by the webGL renderer to draw the primitive graphics data

name: WebGLRenderer
description:
The WebGLRenderer draws the stage and all its content onto a webGL enabled canvas. This renderer
should be used for browsers that support webGL. This Render works by automatically managing webGLBatchs.
So no need for Sprite Batches or Sprite Clouds.
Don't forget to add the view to your DOM or you will not see anything :)

params.description: the width of the canvas view
params.name: width

params.description: the height of the canvas view
params.name: height

params.description: The optional renderer parameters
params.name: options

params.description: the canvas to use as a view, optional
params.name: options.view

params.description: If the render view is transparent, default false
params.name: options.transparent

params.description: If the render view is automatically resized, default false
params.name: options.autoResize

params.description: sets antialias (only applicable in chrome at the moment)
params.name: options.antialias

params.description: enables drawing buffer preservation, enable this if you need to call toDataUrl on the webgl context
params.name: options.preserveDrawingBuffer

params.description: the resolution of the renderer retina would be 2
params.name: options.resolution

params.description: the current WebGL drawing context
params.name: gl

params.description: the current WebGL drawing context
params.name: gl

params.description: the horizontal range of the filter
params.name: width

params.description: the vertical range of the filter
params.name: height

params.description: See {{#crossLink "PIXI/scaleModes:property"}}PIXI.scaleModes{{/crossLink}} for possible values

name: CanvasMaskManager
description: A set of functions used to handle masking.

name: CanvasTinter
description: Utility methods for Sprite/Texture tinting.

name: CanvasRenderer
description:
The CanvasRenderer draws the Stage and all its content onto a 2d canvas. This renderer should be used for browsers that do not support webGL.
Don't forget to add the CanvasRenderer.view to your DOM or you will not see anything :)

params.description: the width of the canvas view

params.description: the height of the canvas view

params.description: If the render view is automatically resized, default false

params.description: the resolution of the renderer retina would be 2

params.name: options.clearBeforeRender

name: BaseTexture
description: A texture stores the information that represents an image. All textures have a base texture.

params.description: the source object (image or canvas)

params.description: See {{#crossLink "PIXI/scaleModes:property"}}PIXI.scaleModes{{/crossLink}} for possible values

name: Texture
description:
A texture stores the information that represents an image or part of an image. It cannot be added
to the display list directly. Instead use it as the texture for a PIXI.Sprite. If no frame is provided then the whole image is used.

params.description: The base texture source to create the texture from

params.description: The rectangle frame of the texture to show

params.description: The area of original texture
params.name: crop

params.description: Trimmed texture rectangle
params.name: trim

params.description: The resolution of the texture being generated

This is the base class for creating a PIXI filter. Currently only webGL supports filters.
If you want to make a custom filter this should be your base class.

params.description: the width of the tiling sprite
params.name: width

params.description: the height of the tiling sprite
params.name: height

name: Circle
description:
Creates a new Circle object with the center coordinate specified by the x and y parameters and the diameter specified by the diameter parameter.
If you call this function without parameters, a circle with x, y, diameter and radius properties set to 0 is created.

params.description: The x coordinate of the center of the circle.
params.name: x

params.description: The y coordinate of the center of the circle.
params.name: y

params.description: The diameter of the circle.
params.name: diameter

name: Ellipse
description: Creates a Ellipse object. A curve on a plane surrounding two focal points.

params.description: The X coordinate of the upper-left corner of the framing rectangle of this ellipse.
params.name: x

params.description: The Y coordinate of the upper-left corner of the framing rectangle of this ellipse.
params.name: y

params.description: The overall width of this ellipse.
params.name: width

params.description: The overall height of this ellipse.
params.name: height

name: Line
description: Creates a new Line object with a start and an end point.

params.description: The x coordinate of the start of the line.
params.name: x1

params.description: The y coordinate of the start of the line.
params.name: y1

params.description: The x coordinate of the end of the line.
params.name: x2

params.description: The y coordinate of the end of the line.
params.name: y2

name: Matrix
description:
The Matrix is a 3x3 matrix mostly used for display transforms within the renderer.

It is represented like so:

| a | b | tx |
| c | d | ty |
| 0 | 0 | 1 |

name: Point
description:
A Point object represents a location in a two-dimensional coordinate system, where x represents the horizontal axis and y represents the vertical axis.
The following code creates a point at (0,0):
`var myPoint = new Phaser.Point();`
You can also use them as 2D Vectors and you'll find different vector related methods in this class.

params.description: The horizontal position of this Point.
params.name: x

params.description: The vertical position of this Point.
params.name: y

name: Polygon
description:
Creates a new Polygon.

The points can be set from a variety of formats:

- An array of Point objects: `[new Phaser.Point(x1, y1), ...]`
- An array of objects with public x/y properties: `[obj1, obj2, ...]`
- An array of paired numbers that represent point coordinates: `[x1,y1, x2,y2, ...]`
- As separate Point arguments: `setTo(new Phaser.Point(x1, y1), ...)`
- As separate objects with public x/y properties arguments: `setTo(obj1, obj2, ...)`
- As separate arguments representing point coordinates: `setTo(x1,y1, x2,y2, ...)`

params.description: The points to set.
params.name: points

name: Rectangle
description:
Creates a new Rectangle object with the top-left corner specified by the x and y parameters and with the specified width and height parameters.
If you call this function without parameters, a Rectangle with x, y, width, and height properties set to 0 is created.

params.description: The x coordinate of the top-left corner of the Rectangle.
params.name: x

params.description: The y coordinate of the top-left corner of the Rectangle.
params.name: y

params.description: The width of the Rectangle. Should always be either zero or a positive value.
params.name: width

params.description: The height of the Rectangle. Should always be either zero or a positive value.
params.name: height

name: RoundedRectangle
description:
The Rounded Rectangle object is an area defined by its position and has nice rounded corners,
as indicated by its top-left corner point (x, y) and by its width and its height.

params.description: The x coordinate of the top-left corner of the Rectangle.
params.name: x

params.description: The y coordinate of the top-left corner of the Rectangle.
params.name: y

params.description: The width of the Rectangle. Should always be either zero or a positive value.
params.name: width

params.description: The height of the Rectangle. Should always be either zero or a positive value.
params.name: height

params.description: Controls the radius of the rounded corners.
params.name: radius

name: Camera
description:
A Camera is your view into the game world. It has a position and size and renders only those objects within its field of view.
The game automatically creates a single Stage sized camera on boot. Move the camera around the world with Phaser.Camera.x/y

params.description: Game reference to the currently running game.
params.name: game

params.description: Not being used at the moment, will be when Phaser supports multiple camera
params.name: id

params.description: Position of the camera on the X axis
params.name: x

params.description: Position of the camera on the Y axis
params.name: y

params.description: The width of the view rectangle
params.name: width

params.description: The height of the view rectangle
params.name: height

name: Create
description:
The Phaser.Create class is a collection of smaller helper methods that allow you to generate game content
quickly and easily, without the need for any external files. You can create textures for sprites and in
coming releases we'll add dynamic sound effect generation support as well (like sfxr).

Access this via `State.create` (or `this.create` from within a State object)

params.description: Game reference to the currently running game.
params.name: game

name: State
description:
This is a base State class which can be extended if you are creating your own game.
It provides quick access to common functions such as the camera, cache, input, match, sound and more.

name: StateManager
description: The State Manager is responsible for loading, setting up and switching game states.

params.description: A reference to the currently running game.
params.name: game

params.description: A State object to seed the manager with.
params.name: pendingState

name: Signal
description:
A Signal is an event dispatch mechansim that supports broadcasting to multiple listeners.

Event listeners are uniquely identified by the listener/callback function and the context.

name: SignalBinding
description:
Object that represents a binding between a Signal and a listener function.
This is an internal constructor and shouldn't be created directly.
Inspired by Joa Ebert AS3 SignalBinding and Robert Penner's Slot classes.

params.description: Reference to Signal object that listener is currently bound to.
params.name: signal

params.description: Handler function bound to the signal.
params.name: listener

params.description: If binding should be executed just once.
params.name: isOnce

params.description: Context on which listener will be executed (object that should represent the `this` variable inside listener function).
params.name: listenerContext

params.description: The priority level of the event listener. (default = 0).
params.name: priority

params.description: Additional arguments to pass to the callback (listener) function. They will be appended after any arguments usually dispatched.
params.name: args

name: Filter
description: This is a base Filter class to use for any Phaser filter development.

params.description: A reference to the currently running game.
params.name: game

params.description: Uniform mappings object
params.name: uniforms

params.description: The fragment shader code. Either an array, one element per line of code, or a string.
params.name: fragmentSrc

name: Plugin
description: This is a base Plugin template to use for any Phaser plugin development.

params.description: A reference to the currently running game.
params.name: game

params.description: The object that owns this plugin, usually Phaser.PluginManager.
params.name: parent

name: PluginManager
description: The Plugin Manager is responsible for the loading, running and unloading of Phaser Plugins.

params.description: A reference to the currently running game.
params.name: game

name: Stage
description:
The Stage controls root level display objects upon which everything is displayed.
It also handles browser visibility handling and the pausing due to loss of focus.

params.description: Game reference to the currently running game.
params.name: game

name: Group
description:
A Group is a container for {@link DisplayObject display objects} including {@link Phaser.Sprite Sprites} and {@link Phaser.Image Images}.

Groups form the logical tree structure of the display/scene graph where local transformations are applied to children.
For instance, all children are also moved/rotated/scaled when the group is moved/rotated/scaled.

In addition, Groups provides support for fast pooling and object recycling.

Groups are also display objects and can be nested as children within other Groups.

params.description: A reference to the currently running game.
params.name: game

params.description:
The parent Group (or other {@link DisplayObject}) that this group will be added to.
    If undefined/unspecified the Group will be added to the {@link Phaser.Game#world Game World}; if null the Group will not be added to any parent.
params.name: parent

params.description: A name for this group. Not used internally but useful for debugging.
params.name: name

params.description: If true this group will be added directly to the Game.Stage instead of Game.World.
params.name: addToStage

params.description: If true all Sprites created with {@link #create} or {@link #createMulitple} will have a physics body created on them. Change the body type with {@link #physicsBodyType}.
params.name: enableBody

params.description: The physics body type to use when physics bodies are automatically added. See {@link #physicsBodyType} for values.
params.name: physicsBodyType

name: World
description:
"This world is but a canvas to our imagination." - Henry David Thoreau

A game has only one world. The world is an abstract place in which all game objects live. It is not bound
by stage limits and can be any size. You look into the world via cameras. All game objects live within
the world at world-based coordinates. By default a world is created the same size as your Stage.

params.description: Reference to the current game instance.
params.name: game

name: FlexGrid
description:
WARNING: This is an EXPERIMENTAL class. The API will change significantly in the coming versions and is incomplete.
Please try to avoid using in production games with a long time to build.
This is also why the documentation is incomplete.

FlexGrid is a a responsive grid manager that works in conjunction with the ScaleManager RESIZE scaling mode and FlexLayers
to provide for game object positioning in a responsive manner.

params.description: The ScaleManager.
params.name: manager

params.description: The width of the game.
params.name: width

params.description: The height of the game.
params.name: height

name: FlexLayer
description:
WARNING: This is an EXPERIMENTAL class. The API will change significantly in the coming versions and is incomplete.
Please try to avoid using in production games with a long time to build.
This is also why the documentation is incomplete.

A responsive grid layer.

params.description: The FlexGrid that owns this FlexLayer.
params.name: manager

params.description: A reference to the Point object used for positioning.
params.name: position

params.description: A reference to the Rectangle used for the layer bounds.
params.name: bounds

params.description: A reference to the Point object used for layer scaling.
params.name: scale

name: ScaleManager
description:
Create a new ScaleManager object - this is done automatically by {@link Phaser.Game}

The `width` and `height` constructor parameters can either be a number which represents pixels or a string that represents a percentage: e.g. `800` (for 800 pixels) or `"80%"` for 80%.

params.description: A reference to the currently running game.
params.name: game

params.description: The width of the game. See above.
params.name: width

params.description: The height of the game. See above.
params.name: height

name: Game
description:
This is where the magic happens. The Game object is the heart of your game,
providing quick access to common functions and handling the boot process.

"Hell, there are no rules here - we're trying to accomplish something."
                                                      Thomas A. Edison

params.description: The width of your game in game pixels. If given as a string the value must be between 0 and 100 and will be used as the percentage width of the parent container, or the browser window if no parent is given.
params.name: width

params.description: The height of your game in game pixels. If given as a string the value must be between 0 and 100 and will be used as the percentage height of the parent container, or the browser window if no parent is given.
params.name: height

params.description: Which renderer to use: Phaser.AUTO will auto-detect, Phaser.WEBGL, Phaser.CANVAS or Phaser.HEADLESS (no rendering at all).
params.name: renderer

params.description: The DOM element into which this games canvas will be injected. Either a DOM ID (string) or the element itself.
params.name: parent

params.description: The default state object. A object consisting of Phaser.State functions (preload, create, update, render) or null.
params.name: state

params.description: Use a transparent canvas background or not.
params.name: transparent

params.description: Draw all image textures anti-aliased or not. The default is for smooth textures, but disable if your game features pixel art.
params.name: antialias

params.description: A physics configuration object to pass to the Physics world on creation.
params.name: physicsConfig

name: Input
description:
Phaser.Input is the Input Manager for all types of Input across Phaser, including mouse, keyboard, touch and MSPointer.
The Input manager is updated automatically by the core game loop.

params.description: Current game instance.
params.name: game

name: Mouse
description:
The Mouse class is responsible for handling all aspects of mouse interaction with the browser.

It captures and processes mouse events that happen on the game canvas object.
It also adds a single `mouseup` listener to `window` which is used to capture the mouse being released
when not over the game.

You should not normally access this class directly, but instead use a Phaser.Pointer object
which normalises all game input for you, including accurate button handling.

params.description: A reference to the currently running game.
params.name: game

name: MSPointer
description:
The MSPointer class handles Microsoft touch interactions with the game and the resulting Pointer objects.

It will work only in Internet Explorer 10+ and Windows Store or Windows Phone 8 apps using JavaScript.
http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/hh673557(v=vs.85).aspx

You should not normally access this class directly, but instead use a Phaser.Pointer object which
normalises all game input for you including accurate button handling.

Please note that at the current time of writing Phaser does not yet support chorded button interactions:
http://www.w3.org/TR/pointerevents/#chorded-button-interactions

params.description: A reference to the currently running game.
params.name: game

name: DeviceButton
description:
DeviceButtons belong to both `Phaser.Pointer` and `Phaser.SinglePad` (Gamepad) instances.

For Pointers they represent the various buttons that can exist on mice and pens, such as the left button, right button,
middle button and advanced buttons like back and forward.

Access them via `Pointer.leftbutton`, `Pointer.rightButton` and so on.

On Gamepads they represent all buttons on the pad: from shoulder buttons to action buttons.

At the time of writing this there are device limitations you should be aware of:

- On Windows, if you install a mouse driver, and its utility software allows you to customize button actions
  (e.g., IntelliPoint and SetPoint), the middle (wheel) button, the 4th button, and the 5th button might not be set,
  even when they are pressed.
- On Linux (GTK), the 4th button and the 5th button are not supported.
- On Mac OS X 10.5 there is no platform API for implementing any advanced buttons.

params.description: A reference to the parent of this button. Either a Pointer or a Gamepad.
params.name: parent

params.description: The button code this DeviceButton is responsible for.
params.name: buttonCode

name: Pointer
description: A Pointer object is used by the Mouse, Touch and MSPoint managers and represents a single finger on the touch screen.

params.description: A reference to the currently running game.
params.name: game

params.description: The ID of the Pointer object within the game. Each game can have up to 10 active pointers.
params.name: id

name: Touch
description:
Phaser.Touch handles touch events with your game. Note: Android 2.x only supports 1 touch event at once, no multi-touch.

You should not normally access this class directly, but instead use a Phaser.Pointer object which normalises all game input for you.

params.description: A reference to the currently running game.
params.name: game

name: InputHandler
description: The Input Handler is bound to a specific Sprite and is responsible for managing all Input events on that Sprite.

params.description: The Sprite object to which this Input Handler belongs.
params.name: sprite

name: Gamepad
description:
The Gamepad class handles gamepad input and dispatches gamepad events.

Remember to call `gamepad.start()`.

HTML5 GAMEPAD API SUPPORT IS AT AN EXPERIMENTAL STAGE!
At moment of writing this (end of 2013) only Chrome supports parts of it out of the box. Firefox supports it
via prefs flags (about:config, search gamepad). The browsers map the same controllers differently.
This class has constants for Windows 7 Chrome mapping of XBOX 360 controller.

params.description: A reference to the currently running game.
params.name: game

name: SinglePad
description: A single Phaser Gamepad

params.description: Current game instance.
params.name: game

params.description: The parent Phaser.Gamepad object (all gamepads reside under this)
params.name: padParent

name: Key
description: If you need more fine-grained control over the handling of specific keys you can create and use Phaser.Key objects.

params.description: Current game instance.
params.name: game

params.description: The key code this Key is responsible for.
params.name: keycode

name: Keyboard
description:
The Keyboard class monitors keyboard input and dispatches keyboard events.

_Be aware_ that many keyboards are unable to process certain combinations of keys due to hardware
limitations known as ghosting. Full details here: http://www.html5gamedevs.com/topic/4876-impossible-to-use-more-than-2-keyboard-input-buttons-at-the-same-time/

params.description: A reference to the currently running game.
params.name: game

name: Angle
description: The Angle Component provides access to an `angle` property; the rotation of a Game Object in degrees.

name: Animation
description: The Animation Component provides a `play` method, which is a proxy to the `AnimationManager.play` method.

name: AutoCull
description:
The AutoCull Component is responsible for providing methods that check if a Game Object is within the bounds of the World Camera.
It is used by the InWorld component.

name: Bounds
description: The Bounds component contains properties related to the bounds of the Game Object.

name: BringToTop
description: The BringToTop Component features quick access to Group sorting related methods.

name: Core
description: Core Component Features.

name: Crop
description:
The Crop component provides the ability to crop a texture based Game Object to a defined rectangle,
which can be updated in real-time.

name: Delta
description: The Delta component provides access to delta values between the Game Objects current and previous position.

name: Destroy
description: The Destroy component is responsible for destroying a Game Object.

name: Events
description:
The Events component is a collection of events fired by the parent game object.

For example to tell when a Sprite has been added to a new group:

`sprite.events.onAddedToGroup.add(yourFunction, this);`

Where `yourFunction` is the function you want called when this event occurs.

The Input-related events will only be dispatched if the Sprite has had `inputEnabled` set to `true`
and the Animation-related events only apply to game objects with animations like {@link Phaser.Sprite}.

params.description: A reference to the game object / Sprite that owns this Events object.
params.name: sprite

name: FixedToCamera
description:
The FixedToCamera component enables a Game Object to be rendered relative to the game camera coordinates, regardless
of where in the world the camera is. This is used for things like sticking game UI to the camera that scrolls as it moves around the world.

name: Health
description:
The Health component provides the ability for Game Objects to have a `health` property
that can be damaged and reset through game code.
Requires the LifeSpan component.

name: InCamera
description: The InCamera component checks if the Game Object intersects with the Game Camera.

name: InputEnabled
description: The InputEnabled component allows a Game Object to have its own InputHandler and process input related events.

name: InWorld
description:
The InWorld component checks if a Game Object is within the Game World Bounds.
An object is considered as being "in bounds" so long as its own bounds intersects at any point with the World bounds.
If the AutoCull component is enabled on the Game Object then it will check the Game Object against the Camera bounds as well.

name: LifeSpan
description: LifeSpan Component Features.

name: LoadTexture
description: The LoadTexture component manages the loading of a texture into the Game Object and the changing of frames.

name: Overlap
description: The Overlap component allows a Game Object to check if it overlaps with the bounds of another Game Object.

name: PhysicsBody
description:
The PhysicsBody component manages the Game Objects physics body and physics enabling.
It also overrides the x and y properties, ensuring that any manual adjustment of them is reflected in the physics body itself.

name: Reset
description: The Reset component allows a Game Object to be reset and repositioned to a new location.

name: ScaleMinMax
description: The ScaleMinMax component allows a Game Object to limit how far it can be scaled by its parent.

name: Smoothed
description: The Smoothed component allows a Game Object to control anti-aliasing of an image based texture.

name: GameObjectFactory
description:
The GameObjectFactory is a quick way to create many common game objects
using {@linkcode Phaser.Game#add `game.add`}.

Created objects are _automatically added_ to the appropriate Manager, World, or manually specified parent Group.

params.description: A reference to the currently running game.
params.name: game

name: GameObjectCreator
description:
The GameObjectCreator is a quick way to create common game objects _without_ adding them to the game world.
The object creator can be accessed with {@linkcode Phaser.Game#make `game.make`}.

params.description: A reference to the currently running game.
params.name: game

name: Sprite
description:
Sprites are the lifeblood of your game, used for nearly everything visual.

At its most basic a Sprite consists of a set of coordinates and a texture that is rendered to the canvas.
They also contain additional properties allowing for physics motion (via Sprite.body), input handling (via Sprite.input),
events (via Sprite.events), animation (via Sprite.animations), camera culling and more. Please see the Examples for use cases.

params.description: A reference to the currently running game.
params.name: game

params.description: The x coordinate (in world space) to position the Sprite at.
params.name: x

params.description: The y coordinate (in world space) to position the Sprite at.
params.name: y

params.description: This is the image or texture used by the Sprite during rendering. It can be a string which is a reference to the Cache entry, or an instance of a RenderTexture or PIXI.Texture.
params.name: key

params.description: If this Sprite is using part of a sprite sheet or texture atlas you can specify the exact frame to use by giving a string or numeric index.
params.name: frame

name: Image
description:
An Image is a light-weight object you can use to display anything that doesn't need physics or animation.
It can still rotate, scale, crop and receive input events. This makes it perfect for logos, backgrounds, simple buttons and other non-Sprite graphics.

params.description: A reference to the currently running game.
params.name: game

params.description: The x coordinate of the Image. The coordinate is relative to any parent container this Image may be in.
params.name: x

params.description: The y coordinate of the Image. The coordinate is relative to any parent container this Image may be in.
params.name: y

params.description: The texture used by the Image during rendering. It can be a string which is a reference to the Cache entry, or an instance of a RenderTexture, BitmapData or PIXI.Texture.
params.name: key

params.description: If this Image is using part of a sprite sheet or texture atlas you can specify the exact frame to use by giving a string or numeric index.
params.name: frame

name: TileSprite
description:
A TileSprite is a Sprite that has a repeating texture. The texture can be scrolled and scaled independently of the TileSprite itself.
Textures will automatically wrap and are designed so that you can create game backdrops using seamless textures as a source.

TileSprites have no input handler or physics bodies by default, both need enabling in the same way as for normal Sprites.

You shouldn't ever create a TileSprite any larger than your actual screen size. If you want to create a large repeating background
that scrolls across the whole map of your game, then you create a TileSprite that fits the screen size and then use the `tilePosition`
property to scroll the texture as the player moves. If you create a TileSprite that is thousands of pixels in size then it will
consume huge amounts of memory and cause performance issues. Remember: use `tilePosition` to scroll your texture and `tileScale` to
adjust the scale of the texture - don't resize the sprite itself or make it larger than it needs.

An important note about texture dimensions:

When running under Canvas a TileSprite can use any texture size without issue. When running under WebGL the texture should ideally be
a power of two in size (i.e. 4, 8, 16, 32, 64, 128, 256, 512, etch pixels width by height). If the texture isn't a power of two
it will be rendered to a blank canvas that is the correct size, which means you may have 'blank' areas appearing to the right and
bottom of your frame. To avoid this ensure your textures are perfect powers of two.

TileSprites support animations in the same way that Sprites do. You add and play animations using the AnimationManager. However
if your game is running under WebGL please note that each frame of the animation must be a power of two in size, or it will receive
additional padding to enforce it to be so.

params.description: A reference to the currently running game.
params.name: game

params.description: The x coordinate (in world space) to position the TileSprite at.
params.name: x

params.description: The y coordinate (in world space) to position the TileSprite at.
params.name: y

params.description: The width of the TileSprite.
params.name: width

params.description: The height of the TileSprite.
params.name: height

params.description: This is the image or texture used by the TileSprite during rendering. It can be a string which is a reference to the Phaser Image Cache entry, or an instance of a RenderTexture, PIXI.Texture or BitmapData.
params.name: key

params.description: If this TileSprite is using part of a sprite sheet or texture atlas you can specify the exact frame to use by giving a string or numeric index.
params.name: frame

name: Rope
description:
A Rope is a Sprite that has a repeating texture. The texture can be scrolled and scaled and will automatically wrap on the edges as it does so.
Please note that Ropes, as with normal Sprites, have no input handler or physics bodies by default. Both need enabling.
Example usage: https://github.com/codevinsky/phaser-rope-demo/blob/master/dist/demo.js

params.description: A reference to the currently running game.
params.name: game

params.description: The x coordinate (in world space) to position the Rope at.
params.name: x

params.description: The y coordinate (in world space) to position the Rope at.
params.name: y

params.description: This is the image or texture used by the Rope during rendering. It can be a string which is a reference to the Cache entry, or an instance of a RenderTexture or PIXI.Texture.
params.name: key

params.description: If this Rope is using part of a sprite sheet or texture atlas you can specify the exact frame to use by giving a string or numeric index.
params.name: frame

params.description: An array of {Phaser.Point}.
params.name: points

name: Button
description:
Create a new `Button` object. A Button is a special type of Sprite that is set-up to handle Pointer events automatically.

The four states a Button responds to are:

* 'Over' - when the Pointer moves over the Button. This is also commonly known as 'hover'.
* 'Out' - when the Pointer that was previously over the Button moves out of it.
* 'Down' - when the Pointer is pressed down on the Button. I.e. touched on a touch enabled device or clicked with the mouse.
* 'Up' - when the Pointer that was pressed down on the Button is released again.

A different texture/frame and activation sound can be specified for any of the states.

Frames can be specified as either an integer (the frame ID) or a string (the frame name); the same values that can be used with a Sprite constructor.

params.description: Current game instance.
params.name: game

params.description: X position of the Button.
params.name: x

params.description: Y position of the Button.
params.name: y

params.description: The image key (in the Game.Cache) to use as the texture for this Button.
params.name: key

params.description: The function to call when this Button is pressed.
params.name: callback

params.description: The context in which the callback will be called (usually 'this').
params.name: callbackContext

params.description: The frame / frameName when the button is in the Over state.
params.name: overFrame

params.description: The frame / frameName when the button is in the Out state.
params.name: outFrame

params.description: The frame / frameName when the button is in the Down state.
params.name: downFrame

params.description: The frame / frameName when the button is in the Up state.
params.name: upFrame

name: SpriteBatch
description:
The SpriteBatch class is a really fast version of the DisplayObjectContainer built purely for speed, so use when you need a lot of sprites or particles.
It's worth mentioning that by default sprite batches are used through-out the renderer, so you only really need to use a SpriteBatch if you have over
1000 sprites that all share the same texture (or texture atlas). It's also useful if running in Canvas mode and you have a lot of un-rotated or un-scaled
Sprites as it skips all of the Canvas setTransform calls, which helps performance, especially on mobile devices.

Please note that any Sprite that is part of a SpriteBatch will not have its bounds updated, so will fail checks such as outOfBounds.

params.description: A reference to the currently running game.
params.name: game

params.description: The parent Group, DisplayObject or DisplayObjectContainer that this Group will be added to. If `undefined` or `null` it will use game.world.
params.name: parent

params.description: A name for this Group. Not used internally but useful for debugging.
params.name: name

params.description: If set to true this Group will be added directly to the Game.Stage instead of Game.World.
params.name: addToStage

name: Particle
description: Create a new `Particle` object. Particles are extended Sprites that are emitted by a particle emitter such as Phaser.Particles.Arcade.Emitter.

params.description: A reference to the currently running game.
params.name: game

params.description: The x coordinate (in world space) to position the Particle at.
params.name: x

params.description: The y coordinate (in world space) to position the Particle at.
params.name: y

params.description: This is the image or texture used by the Particle during rendering. It can be a string which is a reference to the Cache entry, or an instance of a RenderTexture or PIXI.Texture.
params.name: key

params.description: If this Particle is using part of a sprite sheet or texture atlas you can specify the exact frame to use by giving a string or numeric index.
params.name: frame

name: BitmapData
description:
A BitmapData object contains a Canvas element to which you can draw anything you like via normal Canvas context operations.
A single BitmapData can be used as the texture for one or many Images/Sprites.
So if you need to dynamically create a Sprite texture then they are a good choice.

params.description: A reference to the currently running game.
params.name: game

params.description: Internal Phaser reference key for the BitmapData.
params.name: key

params.description: The width of the BitmapData in pixels. If undefined or zero it's set to a default value.
params.name: width

params.description: The height of the BitmapData in pixels. If undefined or zero it's set to a default value.
params.name: height

name: Graphics
description: The Graphics class contains methods used to draw primitive shapes such as lines, circles and rectangles to the display, and color and fill them.

name: GraphicsData
description: A GraphicsData object.

params.description: the width of the line to draw
params.name: lineWidth

params.description: the color of the line to draw
params.name: lineColor

params.description: the alpha of the line to draw
params.name: lineAlpha

params.description: the color of the fill
params.name: fillColor

params.description: the alpha of the fill
params.name: fillAlpha

params.description: whether or not the shape is filled with a colour
params.name: fill

params.description: The shape object to draw.
params.name: shape

name: Graphics
description: Creates a new `Graphics` object.

params.description: Current game instance.
params.name: game

params.description: X position of the new graphics object.
params.name: x

params.description: Y position of the new graphics object.
params.name: y

name: RenderTexture
description:
A RenderTexture is a special texture that allows any displayObject to be rendered to it. It allows you to take many complex objects and
render them down into a single quad (on WebGL) which can then be used to texture other display objects with. A way of generating textures at run-time.

params.description: Current game instance.
params.name: game

params.description: Internal Phaser reference key for the render texture.
params.name: key

params.description: The width of the render texture.
params.name: width

params.description: The height of the render texture.
params.name: height

params.description: The key of the RenderTexture in the Cache, if stored there.
params.name: key

params.description: One of the Phaser.scaleModes consts.
params.name: scaleMode

params.description: The resolution of the texture being generated.
params.name: resolution

name: Text
description:
Create a new game object for displaying Text.

This uses a local hidden Canvas object and renders the type into it. It then makes a texture from this for rendering to the view.
Because of this you can only display fonts that are currently loaded and available to the browser: fonts must be pre-loaded.

See {@link http://www.jordanm.co.uk/tinytype this compatibility table} for the available default fonts across mobile browsers.

params.description: Current game instance.
params.name: game

params.description: X position of the new text object.
params.name: x

params.description: Y position of the new text object.
params.name: y

params.description: The actual text that will be written.
params.name: text

params.description: The style properties to be set on the Text.
params.name: style

params.description: The style and size of the font.
params.name: style.font

params.description: The style of the font (eg. 'italic'): overrides the value in `style.font`.
params.name: style.fontStyle

params.description: The variant of the font (eg. 'small-caps'): overrides the value in `style.font`.
params.name: style.fontVariant

params.description: The weight of the font (eg. 'bold'): overrides the value in `style.font`.
params.name: style.fontWeight

params.description: The size of the font (eg. 32 or '32px'): overrides the value in `style.font`.
params.name: style.fontSize

params.description: A canvas fillstyle that will be used as the background for the whole Text object. Set to `null` to disable.
params.name: style.backgroundColor

params.description: A canvas fillstyle that will be used on the text eg 'red', '#00FF00'.
params.name: style.fill

params.description: Horizontal alignment of each line in multiline text. Can be: 'left', 'center' or 'right'. Does not affect single lines of text (see `textBounds` and `boundsAlignH` for that).
params.name: style.align

params.description: Horizontal alignment of the text within the `textBounds`. Can be: 'left', 'center' or 'right'.
params.name: style.boundsAlignH

params.description: Vertical alignment of the text within the `textBounds`. Can be: 'top', 'middle' or 'bottom'.
params.name: style.boundsAlignV

params.description: A canvas stroke style that will be used on the text stroke eg 'blue', '#FCFF00'.
params.name: style.stroke

params.description: A number that represents the thickness of the stroke. Default is 0 (no stroke).
params.name: style.strokeThickness

params.description: Indicates if word wrap should be used.
params.name: style.wordWrap

params.description: The width in pixels at which text will wrap.
params.name: style.wordWrapWidth

params.description: The size (in pixels) of the tabs, for when text includes tab characters. 0 disables. Can be an array of varying tab sizes, one per tab stop.
params.name: style.tabs

name: BitmapText
description:
BitmapText objects work by taking a texture file and an XML or JSON file that describes the font structure.
It then generates a new Sprite object for each letter of the text, proportionally spaced out and aligned to
match the font structure.

BitmapText objects are less flexible than Text objects, in that they have less features such as shadows, fills and the ability
to use Web Fonts, however you trade this flexibility for rendering speed. You can also create visually compelling BitmapTexts by
processing the font texture in an image editor, applying fills and any other effects required.

To create multi-line text insert \r, \n or \r\n escape codes into the text string.

If you are having performance issues due to the volume of sprites being rendered, and do not require the text to be constantly
updating, you can use BitmapText.generateTexture to create a static texture from this BitmapText.

To create a BitmapText data files you can use:

BMFont (Windows, free): http://www.angelcode.com/products/bmfont/
Glyph Designer (OS X, commercial): http://www.71squared.com/en/glyphdesigner
Littera (Web-based, free): http://kvazars.com/littera/

For most use cases it is recommended to use XML. If you wish to use JSON, the formatting should be equal to the result of
converting a valid XML file through the popular X2JS library. An online tool for conversion can be found here: http://codebeautify.org/xmltojson

params.description: A reference to the currently running game.
params.name: game

params.description: X coordinate to display the BitmapText object at.
params.name: x

params.description: Y coordinate to display the BitmapText object at.
params.name: y

params.description: The key of the BitmapText as stored in Phaser.Cache.
params.name: font

params.description: The text that will be rendered. This can also be set later via BitmapText.text.
params.name: text

params.description: The size the font will be rendered at in pixels.
params.name: size

params.description: The alignment of multi-line text. Has no effect if there is only one line of text.
params.name: align

name: RetroFont
description:
A Retro Font is similar to a BitmapFont, in that it uses a texture to render the text. However unlike a BitmapFont every character in a RetroFont
is the same size. This makes it similar to a sprite sheet. You typically find font sheets like this from old 8/16-bit games and demos.

params.description: Current game instance.
params.name: game

params.description: The font set graphic set as stored in the Game.Cache.
params.name: key

params.description: The width of each character in the font set.
params.name: characterWidth

params.description: The height of each character in the font set.
params.name: characterHeight

params.description: The characters used in the font set, in display order. You can use the TEXT_SET consts for common font set arrangements.
params.name: chars

params.description: The number of characters per row in the font set. If not given charsPerRow will be the image width / characterWidth.
params.name: charsPerRow

params.description: If the characters in the font set have horizontal spacing between them set the required amount here.
params.name: xSpacing

params.description: If the characters in the font set have vertical spacing between them set the required amount here.
params.name: ySpacing

params.description: If the font set doesn't start at the top left of the given image, specify the X coordinate offset here.
params.name: xOffset

params.description: If the font set doesn't start at the top left of the given image, specify the Y coordinate offset here.
params.name: yOffset

name: Rope
description:
A Rope is a Sprite that has a repeating texture. The texture can be scrolled and scaled and will automatically wrap on the edges as it does so.
Please note that Ropes, as with normal Sprites, have no input handler or physics bodies by default. Both need enabling.
Example usage: https://github.com/codevinsky/phaser-rope-demo/blob/master/dist/demo.js

params.description: A reference to the currently running game.
params.name: game

params.description: The x coordinate (in world space) to position the Rope at.
params.name: x

params.description: The y coordinate (in world space) to position the Rope at.
params.name: y

params.description: This is the image or texture used by the Rope during rendering. It can be a string which is a reference to the Cache entry, or an instance of a RenderTexture or PIXI.Texture.
params.name: key

params.description: If this Rope is using part of a sprite sheet or texture atlas you can specify the exact frame to use by giving a string or numeric index.
params.name: frame

params.description: An array of {Phaser.Point}.
params.name: points

name: TileSprite
description:
A TileSprite is a Sprite that has a repeating texture. The texture can be scrolled and scaled independently of the TileSprite itself.
Textures will automatically wrap and are designed so that you can create game backdrops using seamless textures as a source.

TileSprites have no input handler or physics bodies by default, both need enabling in the same way as for normal Sprites.

You shouldn't ever create a TileSprite any larger than your actual screen size. If you want to create a large repeating background
that scrolls across the whole map of your game, then you create a TileSprite that fits the screen size and then use the `tilePosition`
property to scroll the texture as the player moves. If you create a TileSprite that is thousands of pixels in size then it will
consume huge amounts of memory and cause performance issues. Remember: use `tilePosition` to scroll your texture and `tileScale` to
adjust the scale of the texture - don't resize the sprite itself or make it larger than it needs.

An important note about texture dimensions:

When running under Canvas a TileSprite can use any texture size without issue. When running under WebGL the texture should ideally be
a power of two in size (i.e. 4, 8, 16, 32, 64, 128, 256, 512, etch pixels width by height). If the texture isn't a power of two
it will be rendered to a blank canvas that is the correct size, which means you may have 'blank' areas appearing to the right and
bottom of your frame. To avoid this ensure your textures are perfect powers of two.

TileSprites support animations in the same way that Sprites do. You add and play animations using the AnimationManager. However
if your game is running under WebGL please note that each frame of the animation must be a power of two in size, or it will receive
additional padding to enforce it to be so.

params.description: A reference to the currently running game.
params.name: game

params.description: The x coordinate (in world space) to position the TileSprite at.
params.name: x

params.description: The y coordinate (in world space) to position the TileSprite at.
params.name: y

params.description: The width of the TileSprite.
params.name: width

params.description: The height of the TileSprite.
params.name: height

params.description: This is the image or texture used by the TileSprite during rendering. It can be a string which is a reference to the Phaser Image Cache entry, or an instance of a RenderTexture, PIXI.Texture or BitmapData.
params.name: key

params.description: If this TileSprite is using part of a sprite sheet or texture atlas you can specify the exact frame to use by giving a string or numeric index.
params.name: frame

name: Device
description: It is not possible to instantiate the Device class manually.

name: DOM
description:
DOM utility class.

Provides a useful Window and Element functions as well as cross-browser compatibility buffer.

Some code originally derived from {@link https://github.com/ryanve/verge verge}.
Some parts were inspired by the research of Ryan Van Etten, released under MIT License 2013.

name: Canvas
description: The Canvas class handles everything related to creating the `canvas` DOM tag that Phaser will use, including styles, offset and aspect ratio.

A collection of useful mathematical functions.

These are normally accessed through `game.math`.

name: RandomDataGenerator
description:
An extremely useful repeatable random data generator.

Based on Nonsense by Josh Faul https://github.com/jocafa/Nonsense.

The random number genererator is based on the Alea PRNG, but is modified.
 - https://github.com/coverslide/node-alea
 - https://github.com/nquinlan/better-random-numbers-for-javascript-mirror
 - http://baagoe.org/en/wiki/Better_random_numbers_for_javascript (original, perm. 404)

params.description: An array of values to use as the seed.
params.name: seeds

name: QuadTree
description:
A QuadTree implementation. The original code was a conversion of the Java code posted to GameDevTuts.
However I've tweaked it massively to add node indexing, removed lots of temp. var creation and significantly increased performance as a result.
Original version at https://github.com/timohausmann/quadtree-js/

params.description: The top left coordinate of the quadtree.
params.name: x

params.description: The top left coordinate of the quadtree.
params.name: y

params.description: The width of the quadtree in pixels.
params.name: width

params.description: The height of the quadtree in pixels.
params.name: height

params.description: The maximum number of objects per node.
params.name: maxObjects
