params.name: level

name: Net
description: Phaser.Net handles browser URL related tasks such as checking host names, domain names and query string manipulation.

params.description: A reference to the currently running game.
params.name: game

name: TweenManager
description:
Phaser.Game has a single instance of the TweenManager through which all Tween objects are created and updated.
Tweens are hooked into the game clock and pause system, adjusting based on the game state.

TweenManager is based heavily on tween.js by http://soledadpenades.com.
The difference being that tweens belong to a games instance of TweenManager, rather than to a global TWEEN object.
It also has callbacks swapped for Signals and a few issues patched with regard to properties and completion errors.
Please see https://github.com/sole/tween.js for a full list of contributors.

params.description: A reference to the currently running game.
params.name: game

name: Tween
description:
A Tween allows you to alter one or more properties of a target object over a defined period of time.
This can be used for things such as alpha fading Sprites, scaling them or motion.
Use `Tween.to` or `Tween.from` to set-up the tween values. You can create multiple tweens on the same object
by calling Tween.to multiple times on the same Tween. Additional tweens specified in this way become "child" tweens and
are played through in sequence. You can use Tween.timeScale and Tween.reverse to control the playback of this Tween and all of its children.

params.description: The target object, such as a Phaser.Sprite or Phaser.Sprite.scale.
params.name: target

params.description: Current game instance.
params.name: game

params.description: The TweenManager responsible for looking after this Tween.
params.name: manager

name: TweenData
description:
A Phaser.Tween contains at least one TweenData object. It contains all of the tween data values, such as the
starting and ending values, the ease function, interpolation and duration. The Tween acts as a timeline manager for
TweenData objects and can contain multiple TweenData objects.

params.description: The Tween that owns this TweenData object.
params.name: parent

name: Easing
description: A collection of easing methods defining ease-in and ease-out curves.

name: Linear
description: Linear easing.

name: Quadratic
description: Quadratic easing.

name: Cubic
description: Cubic easing.

name: Quartic
description: Quartic easing.

name: Quintic
description: Quintic easing.

name: Sinusoidal
description: Sinusoidal easing.

name: Exponential
description: Exponential easing.

name: Circular
description: Circular easing.

name: Elastic
description: Elastic easing.

name: Back
description: Back easing.

name: Bounce
description: Bounce easing.

name: Time
description:
This is the core internal game clock.

It manages the elapsed time and calculation of elapsed values, used for game object motion and tweens,
and also handles the standard Timer pool.

To create a general timed event, use the master {@link Phaser.Timer} accessible through {@link Phaser.Time.events events}.

params.description: A reference to the currently running game.
params.name: game

name: Timer
description:
A Timer is a way to create small re-usable (or disposable) objects that wait for a specific moment in time,
and then run the specified callbacks.

You can add many events to a Timer, each with their own delays. A Timer uses milliseconds as its unit of time (there are 1000 ms in 1 second).
So a delay to 250 would fire the event every quarter of a second.

Timers are based on real-world (not physics) time, adjusted for game pause durations.

params.description: A reference to the currently running game.
params.name: game

params.description: If true, the timer will automatically destroy itself after all the events have been dispatched (assuming no looping events).
params.name: autoDestroy

name: TimerEvent
description:
A TimerEvent is a single event that is processed by a Phaser.Timer.

It consists of a delay, which is a value in milliseconds after which the event will fire.
When the event fires it calls a specific callback with the specified arguments.

Use {@link Phaser.Timer#add}, {@link Phaser.Timer#add}, or {@link Phaser.Timer#add} methods to create a new event.

params.description: The Timer object that this TimerEvent belongs to.
params.name: timer

params.description: The delay in ms at which this TimerEvent fires.
params.name: delay

params.description: The tick is the next game clock time that this event will fire at.
params.name: tick

params.description: If this TimerEvent repeats it will do so this many times.
params.name: repeatCount

params.description: True if this TimerEvent loops, otherwise false.
params.name: loop

params.description: The callback that will be called when the TimerEvent occurs.
params.name: callback

params.description: The context in which the callback will be called.
params.name: callbackContext

params.description: Additional arguments to be passed to the callback.
params.name: arguments

name: AnimationManager
description:
The Animation Manager is used to add, play and update Phaser Animations.
Any Game Object such as Phaser.Sprite that supports animation contains a single AnimationManager instance.

params.description: A reference to the Game Object that owns this AnimationManager.
params.name: sprite

name: Animation
description:
An Animation instance contains a single animation and the controls to play it.

It is created by the AnimationManager, consists of Animation.Frame objects and belongs to a single Game Object such as a Sprite.

params.description: A reference to the currently running game.
params.name: game

params.description: A reference to the owner of this Animation.
params.name: parent

params.description: The unique name for this animation, used in playback commands.
params.name: name

params.description: The FrameData object that contains all frames used by this Animation.
params.name: frameData

params.description: An array of numbers or strings indicating which frames to play in which order.
params.name: frames

params.description: The speed at which the animation should play. The speed is given in frames per second.
params.name: frameRate

params.description: Whether or not the animation is looped or just plays once.
params.name: loop

params.description: Should this animation loop when it reaches the end or play through once.
params.name: loop

name: Frame
description: A Frame is a single frame of an animation and is part of a FrameData collection.

params.description: The index of this Frame within the FrameData set it is being added to.
params.name: index

params.description: X position of the frame within the texture image.
params.name: x

params.description: Y position of the frame within the texture image.
params.name: y

params.description: Width of the frame within the texture image.
params.name: width

params.description: Height of the frame within the texture image.
params.name: height

params.description: The name of the frame. In Texture Atlas data this is usually set to the filename.
params.name: name

name: FrameData
description: FrameData is a container for Frame objects, which are the internal representation of animation data in Phaser.

name: AnimationParser
description: Responsible for parsing sprite sheet and JSON data into the internal FrameData format that Phaser uses for animations.

name: Cache
description:
Phaser has one single cache in which it stores all assets.

The cache is split up into sections, such as images, sounds, video, json, etc. All assets are stored using
a unique string-based key as their identifier. Assets stored in different areas of the cache can have the
same key, for example 'playerWalking' could be used as the key for both a sprite sheet and an audio file,
because they are unique data types.

The cache is automatically populated by the Phaser.Loader. When you use the loader to pull in external assets
such as images they are automatically placed into their respective cache. Most common Game Objects, such as
Sprites and Videos automatically query the cache to extract the assets they need on instantiation.

You can access the cache from within a State via `this.cache`. From here you can call any public method it has,
including adding new entries to it, deleting them or querying them.

Understand that almost without exception when you get an item from the cache it will return a reference to the
item stored in the cache, not a copy of it. Therefore if you retrieve an item and then modify it, the original
object in the cache will also be updated, even if you don't put it back into the cache again.

By default when you change State the cache is _not_ cleared, although there is an option to clear it should
your game require it. In a typical game set-up the cache is populated once after the main game has loaded and
then used as an asset store.

params.description: A reference to the currently running game.
params.name: game

name: Loader
description:
The Loader handles loading all external content such as Images, Sounds, Texture Atlases and data files.

The loader uses a combination of tag loading (eg. Image elements) and XHR and provides progress and completion callbacks.

Parallel loading (see {@link #enableParallel}) is supported and enabled by default.
Load-before behavior of parallel resources is controlled by synchronization points as discussed in {@link #withSyncPoint}.

Texture Atlases can be created with tools such as [Texture Packer](https://www.codeandweb.com/texturepacker/phaser) and
[Shoebox](http://renderhjs.net/shoebox/)

params.description: A reference to the currently running game.
params.name: game

name: LoaderParser
description: Phaser.LoaderParser parses data objects from Phaser.Loader that need more preparation before they can be inserted into the Cache.

name: AudioSprite
description:
Audio Sprites are a combination of audio files and a JSON configuration.
The JSON follows the format of that created by https://github.com/tonistiigi/audiosprite

params.description: Reference to the current game instance.
params.name: game

params.description: Asset key for the sound.
params.name: key

name: Sound
description: The Sound class constructor.

params.description: Reference to the current game instance.
params.name: game

params.description: Asset key for the sound.
params.name: key

params.description: Default value for the volume, between 0 and 1.
params.name: volume

params.description: Whether or not the sound will loop.
params.name: loop

name: SoundManager
description:
The Sound Manager is responsible for playing back audio via either the Legacy HTML Audio tag or via Web Audio if the browser supports it.
Note: On Firefox 25+ on Linux if you have media.gstreamer disabled in about:config then it cannot play back mp3 or m4a files.
The audio file type and the encoding of those files are extremely important. Not all browsers can play all audio formats.
There is a good guide to what's supported here: http://hpr.dogphilosophy.net/test/

If you are reloading a Phaser Game on a page that never properly refreshes (such as in an AngularJS project) then you will quickly run out
of AudioContext nodes. If this is the case create a global var called PhaserGlobal on the window object before creating the game. The active
AudioContext will then be saved to window.PhaserGlobal.audioContext when the Phaser game is destroyed, and re-used when it starts again.

Mobile warning: There are some mobile devices (certain iPad 2 and iPad Mini revisions) that cannot play 48000 Hz audio.
When they try to play the audio becomes extremely distorted and buzzes, eventually crashing the sound system.
The solution is to use a lower encoding rate such as 44100 Hz.

params.description: Reference to the current game instance.
params.name: game

name: Debug
description:
A collection of methods for displaying debug information about game objects.
If your game is running in WebGL then Debug will create a Sprite that is placed at the top of the Stage display list and bind a canvas texture
to it, which must be uploaded every frame. Be advised: this is very expensive, especially in browsers like Firefox. So please only enable Debug
in WebGL mode if you really need it (or your desktop can cope with it well) and disable it for production!
If your game is using a Canvas renderer then the debug information is literally drawn on the top of the active game canvas and no Sprite is used.

params.description: A reference to the currently running game.
params.name: game

name: ArraySet
description:
ArraySet is a Set data structure (items must be unique within the set) that also maintains order.
This allows specific items to be easily added or removed from the Set.

Item equality (and uniqueness) is determined by the behavior of `Array.indexOf`.

This used primarily by the Input subsystem.

params.description: The backing array: if specified the items in the list _must_ be unique, per `Array.indexOf`, and the ownership of the array _should_ be relinquished to the ArraySet.
params.name: list

name: ArrayUtils
description: Utility functions for dealing with Arrays.

name: Color
description: The Phaser.Color class is a set of static methods that assist in color manipulation and conversion.

name: LinkedList
description:
A basic Linked List data structure.

This implementation _modifies_ the `prev` and `next` properties of each item added:
- The `prev` and `next` properties must be writable and should not be used for any other purpose.
- Items _cannot_ be added to multiple LinkedLists at the same time.
- Only objects can be added.

name: Physics
description:
The Physics Manager is responsible for looking after all of the running physics systems.
Phaser supports 4 physics systems: Arcade Physics, P2, Ninja Physics and Box2D via a commercial plugin.

Game Objects (such as Sprites) can only belong to 1 physics system, but you can have multiple systems active in a single game.

For example you could have P2 managing a polygon-built terrain landscape that an vehicle drives over, while it could be firing bullets that use the
faster (due to being much simpler) Arcade Physics system.

params.description: A reference to the currently running game.
params.name: game

params.description: A physics configuration object to pass to the Physics world on creation.
params.name: physicsConfig

name: Arcade
description: The Arcade Physics world. Contains Arcade Physics related collision, overlap and motion methods.

params.description: reference to the current game instance.
params.name: game

name: Body
description:
The Physics Body is linked to a single Sprite. All physics operations should be performed against the body rather than
the Sprite itself. For example you can set the velocity, acceleration, bounce values etc all on the Body.

params.description: The Sprite object this physics body belongs to.
params.name: sprite

name: TilemapCollision
description: The Arcade Physics tilemap collision methods.

params.description: reference to the current game instance.
params.name: game

name: P2
description:
This is your main access to the P2 Physics World.
From here you can create materials, listen for events and add bodies into the physics simulation.

params.description: Reference to the current game instance.
params.name: game

params.description: Physics configuration object passed in from the game constructor.
params.name: config

name: FixtureList
description:
Allow to access a list of created fixture (coming from Body#addPhaserPolygon)
which itself parse the input from PhysicsEditor with the custom phaser exporter.
You can access fixtures of a Body by a group index or even by providing a fixture Key.
You can set the fixture key and also the group index for a fixture in PhysicsEditor.
This gives you the power to create a complex body built of many fixtures and modify them
during runtime (to remove parts, set masks, categories & sensor properties)

params.description: A list of fixtures (from Phaser.Physics.P2.Body#addPhaserPolygon)
params.name: list

name: PointProxy
description: A PointProxy is an internal class that allows for direct getter/setter style property access to Arrays and TypedArrays.

params.description: A reference to the P2 World.
params.name: world

params.description: The object to bind to.
params.name: destination

name: InversePointProxy
description: A InversePointProxy is an internal class that allows for direct getter/setter style property access to Arrays and TypedArrays but inverses the values on set.

params.description: A reference to the P2 World.
params.name: world

params.description: The object to bind to.
params.name: destination

name: Body
description:
The Physics Body is typically linked to a single Sprite and defines properties that determine how the physics body is simulated.
These properties affect how the body reacts to forces, what forces it generates on itself (to simulate friction), and how it reacts to collisions in the scene.
In most cases, the properties are used to simulate physical effects. Each body also has its own property values that determine exactly how it reacts to forces and collisions in the scene.
By default a single Rectangle shape is added to the Body that matches the dimensions of the parent Sprite. See addShape, removeShape, clearShapes to add extra shapes around the Body.
Note: When bound to a Sprite to avoid single-pixel jitters on mobile devices we strongly recommend using Sprite sizes that are even on both axis, i.e. 128x128 not 127x127.
Note: When a game object is given a P2 body it has its anchor x/y set to 0.5, so it becomes centered.

params.description: Game reference to the currently running game.
params.name: game

params.description: The Sprite object this physics body belongs to.
params.name: sprite

params.description: The x coordinate of this Body.
params.name: x

params.description: The y coordinate of this Body.
params.name: y

params.description: The default mass of this Body (0 = static).
params.name: mass

name: BodyDebug
description:
Draws a P2 Body to a Graphics instance for visual debugging.
Needless to say, for every body you enable debug drawing on, you are adding processor and graphical overhead.
So use sparingly and rarely (if ever) in production code.

Also be aware that the Debug body is only updated when the Sprite it is connected to changes position. If you
manipulate the sprite in any other way (such as moving it to another Group or bringToTop, etc) then you will
need to manually adjust its BodyDebug as well.

params.description: Game reference to the currently running game.

A P2 Material.

name: Tilemap
description:
Creates a new Phaser.Tilemap object. The map can either be populated with data from a Tiled JSON file or from a CSV file.
To do this pass the Cache key as the first parameter. When using Tiled data you need only provide the key.
When using CSV data you must provide the key and the tileWidth and tileHeight parameters.
If creating a blank tilemap to be populated later, you can either specify no parameters at all and then use `Tilemap.create` or pass the map and tile dimensions here.
Note that all Tilemaps use a base tile size to calculate dimensions from, but that a TilemapLayer may have its own unique tile size that overrides it.
A Tile map is rendered to the display using a TilemapLayer. It is not added to the display list directly itself.
A map may have multiple layers. You can perform operations on the map data such as copying, pasting, filling and shuffling the tiles around.

params.description: Game reference to the currently running game.
params.name: game

params.description: The key of the tilemap data as stored in the Cache. If you're creating a blank map either leave this parameter out or pass `null`.
params.name: key

params.description: The pixel width of a single map tile. If using CSV data you must specify this. Not required if using Tiled map data.
params.name: tileWidth

params.description: The pixel height of a single map tile. If using CSV data you must specify this. Not required if using Tiled map data.
params.name: tileHeight

params.description: The width of the map in tiles. If this map is created from Tiled or CSV data you don't need to specify this.
params.name: width

params.description: The height of the map in tiles. If this map is created from Tiled or CSV data you don't need to specify this.
params.name: height

name: TilemapLayer
description:
A TilemapLayer is a Phaser.Image/Sprite that renders a specific TileLayer of a Tilemap.

Since a TilemapLayer is a Sprite it can be moved around the display, added to other groups or display objects, etc.

By default TilemapLayers have fixedToCamera set to `true`. Changing this will break Camera follow and scrolling behavior.

params.description: Game reference to the currently running game.
params.name: game

params.description: The tilemap to which this layer belongs.
params.name: tilemap

params.description: The index of the TileLayer to render within the Tilemap.
params.name: index

params.description: Width of the renderable area of the layer (in pixels).
params.name: width

params.description: Height of the renderable area of the layer (in pixels).
params.name: height

name: TilemapParser
description: Phaser.TilemapParser parses data objects from Phaser.Loader that need more preparation before they can be inserted into a Tilemap.

A Tile set is a combination of an image containing the tiles and collision data per tile.

Tilesets are normally created automatically when Tiled data is loaded.

Emitter is a lightweight particle emitter that uses Arcade Physics.
It can be used for one-time explosions or for continuous effects like rain and fire.
All it really does is launch Particle objects out at set intervals, and fixes their positions and velocities accordingly.

name: Video
description:
A Video object that takes a previously loaded Video from the Phaser Cache and handles playback of it.

Alternatively it takes a getUserMedia feed from an active webcam and streams the contents of that to
the Video instead (see `startMediaStream` method)

The video can then be applied to a Sprite as a texture. If multiple Sprites share the same Video texture and playback
changes (i.e. you pause the video, or seek to a new time) then this change will be seen across all Sprites simultaneously.

Due to a bug in IE11 you cannot play a video texture to a Sprite in WebGL. For IE11 force Canvas mode.

If you need each Sprite to be able to play a video fully independently then you will need one Video object per Sprite.
Please understand the obvious performance implications of doing this, and the memory required to hold videos in RAM.

On some mobile browsers such as iOS Safari, you cannot play a video until the user has explicitly touched the screen.
This works in the same way as audio unlocking. Phaser will handle the touch unlocking for you, however unlike with audio
it's worth noting that every single Video needs to be touch unlocked, not just the first one. You can use the `changeSource`
method to try and work around this limitation, but see the method help for details.

Small screen devices, especially iPod and iPhone will launch the video in its own native video player,
outside of the Safari browser. There is no way to avoid this, it's a device imposed limitation.

params.description: A reference to the currently running game.
params.name: game

params.description: The key of the video file in the Phaser.Cache that this Video object will play. Set to `null` or leave undefined if you wish to use a webcam as the source. See `startMediaStream` to start webcam capture.
params.name: key

params.description: If the video hasn't been loaded then you can provide a full URL to the file here (make sure to set key to null)
params.name: url

description: Add equations. Same as .addEquation, but this time the argument is an array of Equations

name: removeEquation
description: Remove an equation.

name: removeAllEquations
description: Remove all currently added equations.

name: tick
description: Ticks one step forward in time. This will move the current overlap state to the "old" overlap state, and create a new one as current.

name: bodiesAreOverlapping
description: Checks if two bodies are currently overlapping.

name: set
description: Set the data for the record

name: getKey
description: Generate a key given two integers

name: set
description: Set a value.

name: reset
description: Remove all data.

name: copy
description: Copy another TupleDictionary. Note that all data in this dictionary will be removed.

params.description: The TupleDictionary to copy into this one.
params.name: dict

name: reset
description: Clean this island from bodies and equations.

name: getBodies
description: Get all unique bodies in this island.

returns.description: An array of Body

name: wantsToSleep
description: Check if the entire island wants to sleep.

name: sleep
description: Make all bodies in the island sleep.

name: visit
description: Visit a node.

name: bfs
description: Runs the search algorithm, starting at a root node. The resulting bodies and equations will be stored in the provided arrays.

params.description: The node to start from
params.name: root

params.description: An array to append resulting Bodies to.
params.name: bds

params.description: An array to append resulting Equations to.
params.name: eqs

name: split
description: Split the world into independent islands. The result is stored in .islands.

returns.description: The generated islands

name: reset
description: Clean this node from bodies and equations.

name: addConstraint
description: Add a constraint to the simulation.
examples:
var constraint = new LockConstraint(bodyA, bodyB);
    world.addConstraint(constraint);

name: addContactMaterial
description: Add a ContactMaterial to the simulation.

name: removeContactMaterial
description: Removes a contact material

name: getContactMaterial
description: Get a contact material given two materials

returns.description: The matching ContactMaterial, or false on fail.

todoList.task: Use faster hash map to lookup from material id's

name: removeConstraint
description: Removes a constraint

name: step
description:
Step the physics world forward in time.

There are two modes. The simple mode is fixed timestepping without interpolation. In this case you only use the first argument. The second case uses interpolation. In that you also provide the time since the function was last used, as well as the maximum fixed timesteps to take.

params.description: The fixed time step size to use.
params.name: dt

params.description: The time elapsed since the function was last called.
params.name: timeSinceLastCalled

params.description: Maximum number of fixed steps to take per function call.
params.name: maxSubSteps

name: runNarrowphase
description: Runs narrowphase for the shape pair i and j.

name: addSpring
description: Add a spring to the simulation

name: removeSpring
description: Remove a spring

name: addBody
description: Add a body to the simulation

todoList.task: What if this is done during step?

name: removeBody
description: Remove a body from the simulation. If this method is called during step(), the body removal is scheduled to after the step.

name: getBodyById
description: Get a body by its id.

returns.description: The body, or false if it was not found.

name: disableBodyCollision
description: Disable collision between two bodies

name: enableBodyCollision
description: Enable collisions between the given two bodies

name: clear
description: Resets the World, removes all bodies, constraints and springs.

name: hitTest
description: Test if a world point overlaps bodies

params.description: Point to use for intersection tests
params.name: worldPoint

params.description: A list of objects to check for intersection
params.name: bodies

params.description: Used for matching against particles and lines. Adds some margin to these infinitesimal objects.
params.name: precision

returns.description: Array of bodies that overlap the point

todoList.task: Should use an api similar to the raycast function
Should probably implement a .containsPoint method for all shapes. Would be more efficient

name: setGlobalStiffness
description: Set the stiffness for all equations and contact materials.

name: setGlobalRelaxation
description: Set the relaxation for all equations and contact materials.

name: raycast
description: Ray cast against all bodies in the world.

returns.description: True if any body was hit.

name: postStep
description: Fired after the step().

name: addBody
description: Fired when a body is added to the world.

name: removeBody
description: Fired when a body is removed from the world.

name: addSpring
description: Fired when a spring is added to the world.

name: impact
description: Fired when a first contact is created between two bodies. This event is fired after the step has been done.

name: postBroadphase
description:
Fired after the Broadphase has collected collision pairs in the world.
Inside the event handler, you can modify the pairs array as you like, to
prevent collisions between objects that you don't want.

params.description: An array of collision pairs. If this array is [body1,body2,body3,body4], then the body pairs 1,2 and 3,4 would advance to narrowphase.
params.name: pairs

name: beginContact
description: Fired when two shapes starts start to overlap. Fired in the narrowphase, during step.

name: endContact
description: Fired when two shapes stop overlapping, after the narrowphase (during step).

name: preSolve
description: Fired just before equations are added to the solver to be solved. Can be used to control what equations goes into the solver.

params.description: An array of contacts to be solved.
params.name: contactEquations

params.description: An array of friction equations to be solved.
params.name: frictionEquations

name: vertices
description: Vertices that this polygon consists of. An array of array of numbers, example: [[0,0],[1,0],..]

name: lowerBound
description: The lower bound of the bounding box.

name: upperBound
description: The upper bound of the bounding box.

name: result
description: The resulting overlapping pairs. Will be filled with results during .getCollisionPairs().

name: world
description: The world to search for collision pairs in. To change it, use .setWorld()

name: boundingVolumeType
description: The bounding volume type to use in the broadphase algorithms. Should be set to Broadphase.AABB or Broadphase.BOUNDING_CIRCLE.

name: enableFriction
description: Whether to make friction equations in the upcoming contacts.

name: enabledEquations
description: Whether to make equations enabled in upcoming contacts.

name: slipForce
description: The friction slip force to use when creating friction equations.

name: frictionCoefficient
description: The friction value to use in the upcoming friction equations.

name: surfaceVelocity
description: Will be the .relativeVelocity in each produced FrictionEquation.

name: contactEquationPool
description: Keeps track of the allocated ContactEquations.

name: frictionEquationPool
description: Keeps track of the allocated ContactEquations.

name: restitution
description: The restitution value to use in the next contact equations.

name: stiffness
description: The stiffness value to use in the next contact equations.

name: relaxation
description: The stiffness value to use in the next contact equations.

name: frictionStiffness
description: The stiffness value to use in the next friction equations.

name: frictionRelaxation
description: The relaxation value to use in the next friction equations.

name: enableFrictionReduction
description: Enable reduction of friction equations. If disabled, a box on a plane will generate 2 contact equations and 2 friction equations. If enabled, there will be only one friction equation. Same kind of simplifications are made  for all collision types.
deprecated: This flag will be removed when the feature is stable enough.

name: contactSkinSize
description: Contact skin size value to use in the next contact equations.

name: from
description: Ray start point.

name: to
description: Ray end point

name: checkCollisionResponse
description: Set to true if you want the Ray to take .collisionResponse flags into account on bodies and shapes.

name: skipBackfaces
description: If set to true, the ray skips any hits with normal.dot(rayDirection) < 0.

name: mode
description: The intersection mode. Should be {{#crossLink "Ray/ANY:property"}}Ray.ANY{{/crossLink}}, {{#crossLink "Ray/ALL:property"}}Ray.ALL{{/crossLink}} or {{#crossLink "Ray/CLOSEST:property"}}Ray.CLOSEST{{/crossLink}}.

name: callback
description: Current, user-provided result callback. Will be used if mode is Ray.ALL.

name: length
description: Length of the ray

name: normal
description: The normal of the hit, oriented in world space.

name: shape
description: The hit shape, or null.

name: body
description: The hit body, or null.

name: faceIndex
description: The index of the hit triangle, if the hit shape was indexable.

name: fraction
description: Distance to the hit, as a fraction. 0 is at the "from" point, 1 is at the "to" point. Will be set to -1 if there was no hit yet.

name: isStopped
description: If the ray should stop traversing.

name: axisList
description: List of bodies currently in the broadphase.

name: axisIndex
description: The axis to sort along. 0 means x-axis and 1 y-axis. If your bodies are more spread out over the X axis, set axisIndex to 0, and you will gain some performance.

name: type
description: The type of constraint. May be one of Constraint.DISTANCE, Constraint.GEAR, Constraint.LOCK, Constraint.PRISMATIC or Constraint.REVOLUTE.

name: equations
description: Equations to be solved in this constraint

name: bodyA
description: First body participating in the constraint.

name: bodyB
description: Second body participating in the constraint.

name: collideConnected
description: Set to true if you want the connected bodies to collide.

name: localAnchorA
description: Local anchor in body A.

name: localAnchorB
description: Local anchor in body B.

name: distance
description: The distance to keep.

name: maxForce
description: Max force to apply.

name: upperLimitEnabled
description: If the upper limit is enabled or not.

name: upperLimit
description: The upper constraint limit.

name: lowerLimitEnabled
description: If the lower limit is enabled or not.

name: lowerLimit
description: The lower constraint limit.

name: position
description: Current constraint position. This is equal to the current distance between the world anchor points.

name: ratio
description: The gear ratio.

name: angle
description: The relative angle

name: localOffsetB
description: The offset of bodyB in bodyA's frame.

name: localAngleB
description: The offset angle of bodyB in bodyA's frame.

name: position
description: The position of anchor A relative to anchor B, along the constraint axis.

name: lowerLimitEnabled
description: Set to true to enable lower limit.

name: upperLimitEnabled
description: Set to true to enable upper limit.

name: lowerLimit
description: Lower constraint limit. The constraint position is forced to be larger than this value.

name: upperLimit
description: Upper constraint limit. The constraint position is forced to be smaller than this value.

name: motorEquation
description: Equation used for the motor.

name: motorEnabled
description: The current motor state. Enable or disable the motor using .enableMotor

name: motorSpeed
description: Set the target speed for the motor.

name: motorEnabled
description: Indicates whether the motor is enabled. Use .enableMotor() to enable the constraint motor.

name: angle
description: The constraint position.

name: lowerLimitEnabled
description: Set to true to enable lower limit

name: upperLimitEnabled
description: Set to true to enable upper limit

name: lowerLimit
description: The lower limit on the constraint angle.

name: upperLimit
description: The upper limit on the constraint angle.

name: contactPointA
description: Vector from body i center of mass to the contact point.

name: contactPointB
description: World-oriented vector from body A center of mass to the contact point.

name: normalA
description: The normal vector, pointing out of body i

name: restitution
description: The restitution to use (0=no bounciness, 1=max bounciness).

name: firstImpact
description: This property is set to true if this is the first impact between the bodies (not persistant contact).

name: shapeA
description: The shape in body i that triggered this contact.

name: shapeB
description: The shape in body j that triggered this contact.

name: minForce
description: Minimum force to apply when solving.

name: maxForce
description: Max force to apply when solving.

name: bodyA
description: First body participating in the constraint

name: bodyB
description: Second body participating in the constraint

name: stiffness
description: The stiffness of this equation. Typically chosen to a large number (~1e7), but can be chosen somewhat freely to get a stable simulation.

name: relaxation
description: The number of time steps needed to stabilize the constraint equation. Typically between 3 and 5 time steps.

name: G
description: The Jacobian entry of this equation. 6 numbers, 3 per body (x,y,angle).

name: needsUpdate
description: Indicates if stiffness or relaxation was changed.

name: multiplier
description: The resulting constraint multiplier from the last solve. This is mostly equivalent to the force produced by the constraint.

name: relativeVelocity
description: Relative velocity.

name: enabled
description: Whether this equation is enabled or not. If true, it will be added to the solver.

name: contactPointA
description: Relative vector from center of body A to the contact point, world oriented.

name: contactPointB
description: Relative vector from center of body B to the contact point, world oriented.

name: t
description: Tangent vector that the friction force will act along. World oriented.

name: contactEquations
description: ContactEquations connected to this friction equation. The contact equations can be used to rescale the max force for the friction. If more than one contact equation is given, then the max force can be set to the average.

name: shapeA
description: The shape in body i that triggered this friction.

todoList.task: Needed? The shape can be looked up via contactEquation.shapeA...

name: shapeB
description: The shape in body j that triggered this friction.

todoList.task: Needed? The shape can be looked up via contactEquation.shapeB...

name: frictionCoefficient
description: The friction coefficient to use.

name: id
description: The contact material identifier

name: materialA
description: First material participating in the contact material

name: materialB
description: Second material participating in the contact material

name: friction
description: Friction to use in the contact of these two materials

name: restitution
description: Restitution to use in the contact of these two materials

name: stiffness
description: Stiffness of the resulting ContactEquation that this ContactMaterial generate

name: relaxation
description: Relaxation of the resulting ContactEquation that this ContactMaterial generate

name: frictionStiffness
description: Stiffness of the resulting FrictionEquation that this ContactMaterial generate

name: frictionRelaxation
description: Relaxation of the resulting FrictionEquation that this ContactMaterial generate

name: surfaceVelocity
description: Will add surface velocity to this material. If bodyA rests on top if bodyB, and the surface velocity is positive, bodyA will slide to the right.

name: contactSkinSize
description: Offset to be set on ContactEquations. A positive value will make the bodies penetrate more into each other. Can be useful in scenes where contacts need to be more persistent, for example when stacking. Aka "cure for nervous contacts".

name: id
description: The material identifier

name: id
description: The body identifyer

name: world
description: The world that this body is added to. This property is set to NULL if the body is not added to any world.

name: shapes
description: The shapes of the body.

name: mass
description: The mass of the body.

name: invMass
description: The inverse mass of the body.

name: inertia
description: The inertia of the body around the Z axis.

name: invInertia
description: The inverse inertia of the body.

name: fixedRotation
description: Set to true if you want to fix the rotation of the body.

name: fixedX
description: Set to true if you want to fix the body movement along the X axis. The body will still be able to move along Y.

name: fixedY
description: Set to true if you want to fix the body movement along the Y axis. The body will still be able to move along X.

name: position
description: The position of the body

name: interpolatedPosition
description: The interpolated position of the body. Use this for rendering.

name: interpolatedAngle
description: The interpolated angle of the body. Use this for rendering.

name: previousPosition
description: The previous position of the body.

name: previousAngle
description: The previous angle of the body.

name: velocity
description: The current velocity of the body.

name: vlambda
description: Constraint velocity that was added to the body during the last step.

name: wlambda
description: Angular constraint velocity that was added to the body during last step.

name: angle
description: The angle of the body, in radians.

name: angularVelocity
description: The angular velocity of the body, in radians per second.

name: force
description: The force acting on the body. Since the body force (and {{#crossLink "Body/angularForce:property"}}{{/crossLink}}) will be zeroed after each step, so you need to set the force before each step.

name: angularForce
description: The angular force acting on the body. See {{#crossLink "Body/force:property"}}{{/crossLink}}.

name: damping
description: The linear damping acting on the body in the velocity direction. Should be a value between 0 and 1.

name: angularDamping
description: The angular force acting on the body. Should be a value between 0 and 1.

name: type
description:
The type of motion this body has. Should be one of: {{#crossLink "Body/STATIC:property"}}Body.STATIC{{/crossLink}}, {{#crossLink "Body/DYNAMIC:property"}}Body.DYNAMIC{{/crossLink}} and {{#crossLink "Body/KINEMATIC:property"}}Body.KINEMATIC{{/crossLink}}.

* Static bodies do not move, and they do not respond to forces or collision.
* Dynamic bodies body can move and respond to collisions and forces.
* Kinematic bodies only moves according to its .velocity, and does not respond to collisions or force.

name: boundingRadius
description: Bounding circle radius.

name: aabb
description: Bounding box of this body.

name: aabbNeedsUpdate
description: Indicates if the AABB needs update. Update it with {{#crossLink "Body/updateAABB:method"}}.updateAABB(){{/crossLink}}.

name: allowSleep
description: If true, the body will automatically fall to sleep. Note that you need to enable sleeping in the {{#crossLink "World"}}{{/crossLink}} before anything will happen.

name: sleepState
description:
One of {{#crossLink "Body/AWAKE:property"}}Body.AWAKE{{/crossLink}}, {{#crossLink "Body/SLEEPY:property"}}Body.SLEEPY{{/crossLink}} and {{#crossLink "Body/SLEEPING:property"}}Body.SLEEPING{{/crossLink}}.

The body is initially Body.AWAKE. If its velocity norm is below .sleepSpeedLimit, the sleepState will become Body.SLEEPY. If the body continues to be Body.SLEEPY for .sleepTimeLimit seconds, it will fall asleep (Body.SLEEPY).

name: sleepSpeedLimit
description: If the speed (the norm of the velocity) is smaller than this value, the body is considered sleepy.

name: sleepTimeLimit
description: If the body has been sleepy for this sleepTimeLimit seconds, it is considered sleeping.

name: gravityScale
description: Gravity scaling factor. If you want the body to ignore gravity, set this to zero. If you want to reverse gravity, set it to -1.

name: collisionResponse
description: Whether to produce contact forces when in contact with other bodies. Note that contacts will be generated, but they will be disabled. That means that this body will move through other bodies, but it will still trigger contact events, etc.

name: idleTime
description: How long the body has been sleeping.

name: ccdSpeedThreshold
description: If the body speed exceeds this threshold, CCD (continuous collision detection) will be enabled. Set it to a negative number to disable CCD completely for this body.

name: ccdIterations
description: The number of iterations that should be used when searching for the time of impact during CCD. A larger number will assure that there's a small penetration on CCD collision, but a small number will give more performance.

name: localAnchorA
description: Anchor for bodyA in local bodyA coordinates.

name: localAnchorB
description: Anchor for bodyB in local bodyB coordinates.

name: restLength
description: Rest length of the spring.

name: restAngle
description: Rest angle of the spring.

name: stiffness
description: Stiffness of the spring.

name: damping
description: Damping of the spring.

name: bodyA
description: First connected body.

name: bodyB
description: Second connected body.

name: length
description: The distance between the end points.

name: radius
description: The radius of the capsule.

name: radius
description: The radius of the circle.

name: vertices
description: Vertices defined in the local frame.

name: axes
description: Axes defined in the local frame.

name: centerOfMass
description: The center of mass of the Convex

name: triangles
description: Triangulated version of this convex. The structure is Array of 3-Arrays, and each subarray contains 3 integers, referencing the vertices.

name: boundingRadius
description: The bounding radius of the convex

name: heights
description: An array of numbers, or height values, that are spread out along the x axis.

name: maxValue
description: Max value of the heights

name: minValue
description: Max value of the heights

name: elementWidth
description: The width of each element

name: length
description: Length of this line

name: body
description: The body this shape is attached to. A shape can only be attached to a single body.

name: position
description: Body-local position of the shape.

name: angle
description: Body-local angle of the shape.

name: type
id
description: Shape object identifier.

name: boundingRadius
description: Bounding circle radius of this shape

name: collisionGroup
description: Collision group that this shape belongs to (bit mask). See this tutorial.

name: collisionResponse
description: Whether to produce contact forces when in contact with other bodies. Note that contacts will be generated, but they will be disabled. That means that this shape will move through other body shapes, but it will still trigger contact events, etc.

name: collisionMask
description: Collision mask of this shape. See .collisionGroup.

name: material
description: Material to use in collisions for this Shape. If this is set to null, the world will use default material properties instead.

name: area
description: Area of this shape.

name: sensor
description: Set to true if you want this shape to be a sensor. A sensor does not generate contacts, but it still reports contact events. This is good if you want to know if a shape is overlapping another shape, without them generating contacts.

name: iterations
description: The max number of iterations to do when solving. More gives better results, but is more expensive.

name: tolerance
description: The error tolerance, per constraint. If the total error is below this limit, the solver will stop iterating. Set to zero for as good solution as possible, but to something larger than zero to make computations faster.

name: useZeroRHS
description: Set to true to set all right hand side terms to zero when solving. Can be handy for a few applications.

name: frictionIterations
description:
Number of solver iterations that are done to approximate normal forces. When these iterations are done, friction force will be computed from the contact normal forces. These friction forces will override any other friction forces set from the World for example.
The solver will use less iterations if the solution is below the .tolerance.

name: usedIterations
description: The number of iterations that were made during the last solve. If .tolerance is zero, this value will always be equal to .iterations, but if .tolerance is larger than zero, and the solver can quit early, then this number will be somewhere between 1 and .iterations.

name: equations
description: Current equations in the solver.

name: equationSortFunction
description: Function that is used to sort all equations before each solve.

name: data
description: The data storage

name: keys
description: Keys that are currently used.

name: equations
description: Current equations in this island.

name: bodies
description: Current bodies in this island.

name: equations
description: The equations to split. Manually fill this array before running .split().

name: islands
description: The resulting {{#crossLink "Island"}}{{/crossLink}}s.

name: nodes
description: The resulting graph nodes.

name: body
description: The body that is contained in this node.

name: neighbors
description: Neighboring IslandNodes

name: equations
description: Equations connected to this node.

name: visited
description: If this node was visiting during the graph traversal.

name: springs
description: All springs in the world. To add a spring to the world, use {{#crossLink "World/addSpring:method"}}{{/crossLink}}.

name: bodies
description: All bodies in the world. To add a body to the world, use {{#crossLink "World/addBody:method"}}{{/crossLink}}.

name: solver
description: The solver used to satisfy constraints and contacts. Default is {{#crossLink "GSSolver"}}{{/crossLink}}.

name: narrowphase
description: The narrowphase to use to generate contacts.

name: islandManager
description: The island manager of this world.

name: gravity
description: Gravity in the world. This is applied on all bodies in the beginning of each step().

name: frictionGravity
description: Gravity to use when approximating the friction max force (mu*mass*gravity).

name: useWorldGravityAsFrictionGravity
description: Set to true if you want .frictionGravity to be automatically set to the length of .gravity.

name: useFrictionGravityOnZeroGravity
description: If the length of .gravity is zero, and .useWorldGravityAsFrictionGravity=true, then switch to using .frictionGravity for friction instead. This fallback is useful for gravityless games.

name: broadphase
description: The broadphase algorithm to use.

name: constraints
description: User-added constraints.

name: defaultMaterial
description: Dummy default material in the world, used in .defaultContactMaterial

name: defaultContactMaterial
description: The default contact material to use, if no contact material was set for the colliding materials.

name: lastTimeStep
description: For keeping track of what time step size we used last step

name: applySpringForces
description: Enable to automatically apply spring forces each step.

name: applyDamping
description: Enable to automatically apply body damping each step.

name: applyGravity
description: Enable to automatically apply gravity each step.

name: solveConstraints
description: Enable/disable constraint solving in each step.

name: contactMaterials
description: The ContactMaterials added to the World.

name: time
description: World time.

name: stepping
description: Is true during step().

name: islandSplit
description: Whether to enable island splitting. Island splitting can be an advantage for both precision and performance. See {{#crossLink "IslandManager"}}{{/crossLink}}.

name: emitImpactEvent
description: Set to true if you want to the world to emit the "impact" event. Turning this off could improve performance.

name: sleepMode
description:
How to deactivate bodies during simulation. Possible modes are: {{#crossLink "World/NO_SLEEPING:property"}}World.NO_SLEEPING{{/crossLink}}, {{#crossLink "World/BODY_SLEEPING:property"}}World.BODY_SLEEPING{{/crossLink}} and {{#crossLink "World/ISLAND_SLEEPING:property"}}World.ISLAND_SLEEPING{{/crossLink}}.
If sleeping is enabled, you might need to {{#crossLink "Body/wakeUp:method"}}wake up{{/crossLink}} the bodies if they fall asleep when they shouldn't. If you want to enable sleeping in the world, but want to disable it for a particular body, see {{#crossLink "Body/allowSleep:property"}}Body.allowSleep{{/crossLink}}.

name: position
description: The coordinate of the object relative to the local coordinates of the parent.

name: scale
description: The scale factor of the object.

name: transformCallback
description:
The transform callback is an optional callback that if set will be called at the end of the updateTransform method and sent two parameters:
This Display Objects worldTransform matrix and its parents transform matrix. Both are PIXI.Matrix object types.
The matrix are passed by reference and can be modified directly without needing to return them.
This ability allows you to check any of the matrix values and perform actions such as clamping scale or limiting rotation, regardless of the parent transforms.

name: transformCallbackContext
description: The context under which the transformCallback is invoked.

name: pivot
description: The pivot point of the displayObject that it rotates around

name: rotation
description: The rotation of the object in radians.

name: alpha
description: The opacity of the object.

name: visible
description: The visibility of the object.

name: hitArea
description:
This is the defined area that will pick up mouse / touch events. It is null by default.
Setting it is a neat way of optimising the hitTest function that the interactionManager will use (as it will not need to hit test all the children)

name: renderable
description: Can this object be rendered

name: parent
description: [read-only] The display object container that contains this display object.

name: stage
description: [read-only] The stage the display object is connected to, or undefined if it is not connected to the stage.

name: worldAlpha
description: [read-only] The multiplied alpha of the displayObject

name: worldPosition
description:
The position of the Display Object based on the world transform.
This value is updated at the end of updateTransform and takes all parent transforms into account.

name: worldScale
description:
The scale of the Display Object based on the world transform.
This value is updated at the end of updateTransform and takes all parent transforms into account.

name: worldRotation
description:
The rotation of the Display Object, in radians, based on the world transform.
This value is updated at the end of updateTransform and takes all parent transforms into account.

name: filterArea
description:
The area the filter is applied to like the hitArea this is used as more of an optimisation
rather than figuring out the dimensions of the displayObject each frame you can set this rectangle

name: children
description: [read-only] The array of children of this container.

name: anchor
description:
The anchor sets the origin point of the texture.
The default is 0,0 this means the texture's origin is the top left
Setting than anchor to 0.5,0.5 means the textures origin is centered
Setting the anchor to 1,1 would mean the textures origin points will be the bottom right corner

name: texture
description: The texture that the sprite is using

name: tint

name: clearBeforeRender
description:
This sets if the WebGLRenderer will clear the context texture or not before the new render pass. If true:
If the Stage is NOT transparent, Pixi will clear to alpha (0, 0, 0, 0).
If the Stage is transparent, Pixi will clear to the target Stage's background color.
Disable this by setting this to false. For example: if your game has a canvas filling background image, you often don't need this set.

description:
This sets if the CanvasRenderer will clear the canvas or not before the new render pass.
If the Stage is NOT transparent Pixi will use a canvas sized fillRect operation every frame to set the canvas background color.
If the Stage is transparent Pixi will use clearRect to clear the canvas every frame.
Disable this by setting this to false. For example if your game has a canvas filling background image you often don't need this set.

name: view
description:
Camera view.
The view into the world we wish to render (by default the game dimensions).
The x/y values are in world coordinates, not screen coordinates, the width/height is how many pixels to render.
Sprites outside of this view are not rendered if Sprite.autoCull is set to `true`. Otherwise they are always rendered.

name: bounds
description:
The Camera is bound to this Rectangle and cannot move outside of it. By default it is enabled and set to the size of the World.
The Rectangle can be located anywhere in the world and updated as often as you like. If you don't wish the Camera to be bound
at all then set this to null. The values can be anything and are in World coordinates, with 0,0 being the top-left of the world.

properties.description: The Rectangle in which the Camera is bounded. Set to null to allow for movement anywhere.

name: onStateChange
description:
onStateChange is a Phaser.Signal that is dispatched whenever the game changes state.

It is dispatched only when the new state is started, which isn't usually at the same time as StateManager.start
is called because state swapping is done in sync with the game loop. It is dispatched *before* any of the new states
methods (such as preload and create) are called, and *after* the previous states shutdown method has been run.

The callback you specify is sent two parameters: the string based key of the new state,
and the second parameter is the string based key of the old / previous state.

properties.description: This is called when the state is set as the active state.
properties.name: onInitCallback

properties.description: This is called when the state starts to load assets.
properties.name: onPreloadCallback

properties.description: This is called when the state preload has finished and creation begins.
properties.name: onCreateCallback

properties.description: This is called when the state is updated, every game loop. It doesn't happen during preload (@see onLoadUpdateCallback).
properties.name: onUpdateCallback

properties.description: This is called post-render. It doesn't happen during preload (see onLoadRenderCallback).
properties.name: onRenderCallback

properties.description: This is called if ScaleManager.scalemode is RESIZE and a resize event occurs. It's passed the new width and height.
properties.name: onResizeCallback

properties.description: This is called before the state is rendered and before the stage is cleared but after all game objects have had their final properties adjusted.
properties.name: onPreRenderCallback

properties.description: This is called when the State is updated during the preload phase.
properties.name: onLoadUpdateCallback

properties.description: This is called when the State is rendered during the preload phase.
properties.name: onLoadRenderCallback

properties.description: This is called when the game is paused.
properties.name: onPausedCallback

properties.description: This is called when the game is resumed from a paused state.
properties.name: onResumedCallback

properties.description: This is called every frame while the game is paused.
properties.name: onPauseUpdateCallback

properties.description: This is called when the state is shut down (i.e. swapped to another state).
properties.name: onShutDownCallback

properties.description: True if the current state has had its `create` method run (if it has one, if not this is true by default).
properties.name: created

name: memorize
description:
Memorize the previously dispatched event?

If an event has been memorized it is automatically dispatched when a new listener is added with {@link #add} or {@link #addOnce}.
Use {@link #forget} to clear any currently memorized event.

name: active
description:
Is the Signal active? Only active signals will broadcast dispatched events.

Setting this property during a dispatch will only affect the next dispatch. To stop the propagation of a signal from a listener use {@link #halt}.

properties.description: Context on which listener will be executed (object that should represent the `this` variable inside listener function).
properties.name: context

properties.description: The number of times the handler function has been called.
properties.name: callCount

name: active
description: If binding is active and should be executed.

name: params
description: Default parameters passed to listener during `Signal.dispatch` and `SignalBinding.execute` (curried parameters).

properties.name: backgroundColor

name: smoothed
description: Enable or disable texture smoothing for all objects on this Stage. Only works for bitmap/image textures. Smoothing is enabled by default.

properties.description: Set to true to smooth all sprites rendered on this Stage, or false to disable smoothing (great for pixel art)
properties.name: smoothed

name: game
description: A reference to the currently running Game.

name: name
description: A name for this group. Not used internally but useful for debugging.

name: z
description:
The z-depth value of this object within its parent container/Group - the World is a Group as well.
This value must be unique for each child in a Group.

name: type
description: Internal Phaser Type value.

properties.description: The const physics body type of this object.
properties.name: physicsType

name: alive
description: The alive property is useful for Groups that are children of other Groups and need to be included/excluded in checks like forEachAlive.

name: exists
description: If exists is true the group is updated, otherwise it is skipped.

name: ignoreDestroy
description: A group with `ignoreDestroy` set to `true` ignores all calls to its `destroy` method.

name: pendingDestroy
description:
A Group is that has `pendingDestroy` set to `true` is flagged to have its destroy method
called on the next logic update.
You can set it directly to flag the Group to be destroyed on its next update.

This is extremely useful if you wish to destroy a Group from within one of its own callbacks
or a callback of one of its children.

name: classType
description:
The type of objects that will be created when using {@link #create} or {@link #createMultiple}.

Any object may be used but it should extend either Sprite or Image and accept the same constructor arguments:
when a new object is created it is passed the following parameters to its constructor: `(game, x, y, key, frame)`.

name: cursor
description:
The current display object that the group cursor is pointing to, if any. (Can be set manually.)

The cursor is a way to iterate through the children in a Group using {@link #next} and {@link #previous}.

name: enableBody
description:
If true all Sprites created by, or added to this group, will have a physics body enabled on them.

The default body type is controlled with {@link #physicsBodyType}.

name: enableBodyDebug
description:
If true when a physics body is created (via {@link #enableBody}) it will create a physics debug object as well.

This only works for P2 bodies.

name: physicsBodyType
description:
If {@link #enableBody} is true this is the type of physics body that is created on new Sprites.

The valid values are {@link Phaser.Physics.ARCADE}, {@link Phaser.Physics.P2}, {@link Phaser.Physics.NINJA}, etc.

name: physicsSortDirection
description:
If this Group contains Arcade Physics Sprites you can set a custom sort direction via this property.

It should be set to one of the Phaser.Physics.Arcade sort direction constants:

Phaser.Physics.Arcade.SORT_NONE
Phaser.Physics.Arcade.LEFT_RIGHT
Phaser.Physics.Arcade.RIGHT_LEFT
Phaser.Physics.Arcade.TOP_BOTTOM
Phaser.Physics.Arcade.BOTTOM_TOP

If set to `null` the Group will use whatever Phaser.Physics.Arcade.sortDirection is set to. This is the default behavior.

name: onDestroy
description: This signal is dispatched when the group is destroyed.

properties.description: The current index of the Group cursor. Advance it with Group.next.
properties.name: cursorIndex

name: fixedToCamera
description:
A Group that is fixed to the camera uses its x/y coordinates as offsets from the top left of the camera. These are stored in Group.cameraOffset.

Note that the cameraOffset values are in addition to any parent in the display list.
So if this Group was in a Group that has x: 200, then this will be added to the cameraOffset.x

name: cameraOffset
description:
If this object is {@link #fixedToCamera} then this stores the x/y position offset relative to the top-left of the camera view.
If the parent of this Group is also `fixedToCamera` then the offset here is in addition to that and should typically be disabled.

name: hash
description:
The hash array is an array belonging to this Group into which you can add any of its children via Group.addToHash and Group.removeFromHash.

Only children of this Group can be added to and removed from the hash.

This hash is used automatically by Phaser Arcade Physics in order to perform non z-index based destructive sorting.
However if you don't use Arcade Physics, or this isn't a physics enabled Group, then you can use the hash to perform your own
sorting and filtering of Group children without touching their z-index (and therefore display draw order)

name: total
description: Total number of existing children in the group.

name: length
description: Total number of children in this group, regardless of exists/alive status.

name: angle
description:
The angle of rotation of the group container, in degrees.

This adjusts the group itself by modifying its local rotation transform.

This has no impact on the rotation/angle properties of the children, but it will update their worldTransform
and on-screen orientation and position.

name: x
description:
The x coordinate of the group container.

You can adjust the group container itself by modifying its coordinates.
This will have no impact on the x/y coordinates of its children, but it will update their worldTransform and on-screen position.

name: y
description:
The y coordinate of the group container.

You can adjust the group container itself by modifying its coordinates.
This will have no impact on the x/y coordinates of its children, but it will update their worldTransform and on-screen position.

name: rotation
description:
The angle of rotation of the group container, in radians.

This will adjust the group container itself by modifying its rotation.
This will have no impact on the rotation value of its children, but it will update their worldTransform and on-screen position.

name: visible
description: The visible state of the group. Non-visible Groups and all of their children are not rendered.

name: alpha
description: The alpha value of the group container.

name: bounds
description:
The World has no fixed size, but it does have a bounds outside of which objects are no longer considered as being "in world" and you should use this to clean-up the display list and purge dead objects.
By default we set the Bounds to be from 0,0 to Game.width,Game.height. I.e. it will match the size given to the game constructor with 0,0 representing the top-left of the display.
However 0,0 is actually the center of the world, and if you rotate or scale the world all of that will happen from 0,0.
So if you want to make a game in which the world itself will rotate you should adjust the bounds so that 0,0 is the center point, i.e. set them to -1000,-1000,2000,2000 for a 2000x2000 sized world centered around 0,0.

properties.description: Bound of this world that objects can not escape from.

properties.name: width

properties.description: The defined height of the World. Sometimes the bounds needs to grow larger than this (if you resize the game) but this retains the original requested dimension.

properties.name: width

properties.description: Gets or sets the current height of the game world. The world can never be smaller than the game (canvas) dimensions.
properties.name: height

properties.name: centerX

properties.description: Gets the Y position corresponding to the center point of the world.
properties.name: centerY

properties.description: Gets a random integer which is lesser than or equal to the current width of the game world.
properties.name: randomX

properties.description: Gets a random integer which is lesser than or equal to the current height of the game world.
properties.name: randomY
