description:
Gets a DeviceButton object from this controller to be stored and referenced locally.
The DeviceButton object can then be polled, have events attached to it, etc.

params.description: The buttonCode of the button, i.e. Phaser.Gamepad.BUTTON_0, Phaser.Gamepad.XBOX360_A, etc.
params.name: buttonCode

returns.description: The DeviceButton object which you can store locally and reference directly.

name: pollStatus
description: Main update function called by Phaser.Gamepad.

name: connect
description: Gamepad connect function, should be called by Phaser.Gamepad.

params.description: The raw gamepad object
params.name: rawPad

name: disconnect
description: Gamepad disconnect function, should be called by Phaser.Gamepad.

name: destroy
description: Destroys this object and associated callback references.

name: processAxisChange
description: Handles changes in axis.

params.description: State of the relevant axis
params.name: axisState

name: processButtonDown
description: Handles button down press.

params.description: Which buttonCode of this button
params.name: buttonCode

params.description: Button value
params.name: value

name: processButtonUp
description: Handles button release.

params.description: Which buttonCode of this button
params.name: buttonCode

params.description: Button value
params.name: value

name: processButtonFloat
description: Handles buttons with floating values (like analog buttons that acts almost like an axis but still registers like a button)

params.description: Which buttonCode of this button
params.name: buttonCode

params.description: Button value (will range somewhere between 0 and 1, but not specifically 0 or 1.
params.name: value

name: axis
description: Returns value of requested axis.

params.description: The index of the axis to check
params.name: axisCode

returns.description: Axis value if available otherwise false

name: isDown
description: Returns true if the button is pressed down.

params.description: The buttonCode of the button to check.
params.name: buttonCode

returns.description: True if the button is pressed down.

name: isUp
description: Returns true if the button is not currently pressed.

params.description: The buttonCode of the button to check.
params.name: buttonCode

returns.description: True if the button is not currently pressed down.

name: justReleased
description: Returns the "just released" state of a button from this gamepad. Just released is considered as being true if the button was released within the duration given (default 250ms).

params.description: The buttonCode of the button to check for.
params.name: buttonCode

params.description: The duration below which the button is considered as being just released.
params.name: duration

returns.description: True if the button is just released otherwise false.

name: justPressed
description: Returns the "just pressed" state of a button from this gamepad. Just pressed is considered true if the button was pressed down within the duration given (default 250ms).

params.description: The buttonCode of the button to check for.
params.name: buttonCode

params.description: The duration below which the button is considered as being just pressed.
params.name: duration

returns.description: True if the button is just pressed otherwise false.

name: buttonValue
description:
Returns the value of a gamepad button. Intended mainly for cases when you have floating button values, for example
analog trigger buttons on the XBOX 360 controller.

params.description: The buttonCode of the button to check.
params.name: buttonCode

returns.description: Button value if available otherwise null. Be careful as this can incorrectly evaluate to 0.

name: reset
description: Reset all buttons/axes of this gamepad.

name: update
description: Called automatically by Phaser.Keyboard.

name: processKeyDown
description: Called automatically by Phaser.Keyboard.

params.description: The DOM event that triggered this.
params.name: event

name: processKeyUp
description: Called automatically by Phaser.Keyboard.

params.description: The DOM event that triggered this.
params.name: event

name: reset
description:
Resets the state of this Key.

This sets isDown to false, isUp to true, resets the time to be the current time, and _enables_ the key.
In addition, if it is a "hard reset", it clears clears any callbacks associated with the onDown and onUp events and removes the onHoldCallback.

params.description: A soft reset won't reset any events or callbacks; a hard reset will.
params.name: hard

name: downDuration
description:
Returns `true` if the Key was pressed down within the `duration` value given, or `false` if it either isn't down,
or was pressed down longer ago than then given duration.

params.description: The duration within which the key is considered as being just pressed. Given in ms.
params.name: duration

returns.description: True if the key was pressed down within the given duration.

name: upDuration
description:
Returns `true` if the Key was pressed down within the `duration` value given, or `false` if it either isn't down,
or was pressed down longer ago than then given duration.

params.description: The duration within which the key is considered as being just released. Given in ms.
params.name: duration

returns.description: True if the key was released within the given duration.

name: addCallbacks
description: Add callbacks to the Keyboard handler so that each time a key is pressed down or released the callbacks are activated.

params.description: The context under which the callbacks are run.
params.name: context

params.description: This callback is invoked every time a key is pressed down.
params.name: onDown

params.description: This callback is invoked every time a key is released.
params.name: onUp

params.description: This callback is invoked every time the onkeypress event is raised.
params.name: onPress

name: addKey
description:
If you need more fine-grained control over a Key you can create a new Phaser.Key object via this method.
The Key object can then be polled, have events attached to it, etc.

params.description: The keycode of the key, i.e. Phaser.Keyboard.UP or Phaser.Keyboard.SPACEBAR
params.name: keycode

returns.description: The Key object which you can store locally and reference directly.

name: addKeys
description:
A practical way to create an object containing user selected hotkeys.

For example: `addKeys( { 'up': Phaser.Keyboard.W, 'down': Phaser.Keyboard.S, 'left': Phaser.Keyboard.A, 'right': Phaser.Keyboard.D } );`

Would return an object containing the properties `up`, `down`, `left` and `right` that you could poll just like a Phaser.Key object.

params.description: A key mapping object, i.e. `{ 'up': Phaser.Keyboard.W, 'down': Phaser.Keyboard.S }` or `{ 'up': 52, 'down': 53 }`.
params.name: keys

returns.description: An object containing user selected properties

name: removeKey
description: Removes a Key object from the Keyboard manager.

params.description: The keycode of the key to remove, i.e. Phaser.Keyboard.UP or Phaser.Keyboard.SPACEBAR
params.name: keycode

name: createCursorKeys
description: Creates and returns an object containing 4 hotkeys for Up, Down, Left and Right.

returns.description: An object containing properties: up, down, left and right. Which can be polled like any other Phaser.Key object.

name: start
description:
Starts the Keyboard event listeners running (keydown and keyup). They are attached to the window.
This is called automatically by Phaser.Input and should not normally be invoked directly.

name: stop
description: Stops the Keyboard event listeners from running (keydown, keyup and keypress). They are removed from the window.

name: destroy
description:
Stops the Keyboard event listeners from running (keydown and keyup). They are removed from the window.
Also clears all key captures and currently created Key objects.

name: addKeyCapture
description:
By default when a key is pressed Phaser will not stop the event from propagating up to the browser.
There are some keys this can be annoying for, like the arrow keys or space bar, which make the browser window scroll.
You can use addKeyCapture to consume the keyboard event for specific keys so it doesn't bubble up to the the browser.
Pass in either a single keycode or an array/hash of keycodes.

params.description: Either a single numeric keycode or an array/hash of keycodes: [65, 67, 68].
params.name: keycode

name: removeKeyCapture
description: Removes an existing key capture.

name: clearCaptures
description: Clear all set key captures.

name: update
description: Updates all currently defined keys.

name: processKeyDown
description: Process the keydown event.

name: processKeyPress
description: Process the keypress event.

name: processKeyUp
description: Process the keyup event.

name: reset
description: Resets all Keys.

params.description: A soft reset won't reset any events or callbacks that are bound to the Keys. A hard reset will.
params.name: hard

name: downDuration
description:
Returns `true` if the Key was pressed down within the `duration` value given, or `false` if it either isn't down,
or was pressed down longer ago than then given duration.

params.description: The keycode of the key to check, i.e. Phaser.Keyboard.UP or Phaser.Keyboard.SPACEBAR
params.name: keycode

params.description: The duration within which the key is considered as being just pressed. Given in ms.
params.name: duration

returns.description: True if the key was pressed down within the given duration, false if not or null if the Key wasn't found.

name: upDuration
description:
Returns `true` if the Key was pressed down within the `duration` value given, or `false` if it either isn't down,
or was pressed down longer ago than then given duration.

params.description: The keycode of the key to check, i.e. Phaser.Keyboard.UP or Phaser.Keyboard.SPACEBAR
params.name: keycode

params.description: The duration within which the key is considered as being just released. Given in ms.
params.name: duration

returns.description: True if the key was released within the given duration, false if not or null if the Key wasn't found.

name: isDown
description: Returns true of the key is currently pressed down. Note that it can only detect key presses on the web browser.

params.description: The keycode of the key to check, i.e. Phaser.Keyboard.UP or Phaser.Keyboard.SPACEBAR
params.name: keycode

returns.description: True if the key is currently down, false if not or null if the Key wasn't found.

name: play
description:
Plays an Animation.

The animation should have previously been created via `animations.add`.

If the animation is already playing calling this again won't do anything.
If you need to reset an already running animation do so directly on the Animation object itself or via `AnimationManager.stop`.

params.description: The name of the animation to be played, e.g. "fire", "walk", "jump". Must have been previously created via 'AnimationManager.add'.
params.name: name

params.description: The framerate to play the animation at. The speed is given in frames per second. If not provided the previously set frameRate of the Animation is used.
params.name: frameRate

params.description: Should the animation be looped after playback. If not provided the previously set loop value of the Animation is used.
params.name: loop

params.description: If set to true when the animation completes (only happens if loop=false) the parent Sprite will be killed.
params.name: killOnComplete

returns.description: A reference to playing Animation.

name: update
description:
Override this method in your own custom objects to handle any update requirements.
It is called immediately after `preUpdate` and before `postUpdate`.
Remember if this Game Object has any children you should call update on those too.

name: postUpdate
description: Internal method called by the World postUpdate cycle.

name: crop
description:
Crop allows you to crop the texture being used to display this Game Object.
Setting a crop rectangle modifies the core texture frame. The Game Object width and height properties will be adjusted accordingly.

Cropping takes place from the top-left and can be modified in real-time either by providing an updated rectangle object to this method,
or by modifying `cropRect` property directly and then calling `updateCrop`.

The rectangle object given to this method can be either a `Phaser.Rectangle` or any other object
so long as it has public `x`, `y`, `width`, `height`, `right` and `bottom` properties.

A reference to the rectangle is stored in `cropRect` unless the `copy` parameter is `true`,
in which case the values are duplicated to a local object.

params.description: The Rectangle used during cropping. Pass null or no parameters to clear a previously set crop rectangle.
params.name: rect

params.description: If false `cropRect` will be stored as a reference to the given rect. If true it will copy the rect values into a local Phaser Rectangle object stored in cropRect.
params.name: copy

name: updateCrop
description:
If you have set a crop rectangle on this Game Object via `crop` and since modified the `cropRect` property,
or the rectangle it references, then you need to update the crop frame by calling this method.

name: destroy
description:
Destroys the Game Object. This removes it from its parent group, destroys the input, event and animation handlers if present
and nulls its reference to `game`, freeing it up for garbage collection.

If this Game Object has the Events component it will also dispatch the `onDestroy` event.

params.description: Should every child of this object have its destroy method called as well?
params.name: destroyChildren

name: destroy
description: Removes all events.

name: revive
description:
Brings a 'dead' Game Object back to life, optionally resetting its health value in the process.

A resurrected Game Object has its `alive`, `exists` and `visible` properties all set to true.

It will dispatch the `onRevived` event. Listen to `events.onRevived` for the signal.

params.description: The health to give the Game Object. Only set if the GameObject has the Health component.
params.name: health

returns.description: This instance.

name: kill
description:
Kills a Game Object. A killed Game Object has its `alive`, `exists` and `visible` properties all set to false.

It will dispatch the `onKilled` event. You can listen to `events.onKilled` for the signal.

Note that killing a Game Object is a way for you to quickly recycle it in an object pool,
it doesn't destroy the object or free it up from memory.

If you don't need this Game Object any more you should call `destroy` instead.

returns.description: This instance.

name: loadTexture
description:
Changes the base texture the Game Object is using. The old texture is removed and the new one is referenced or fetched from the Cache.

If your Game Object is using a frame from a texture atlas and you just wish to change to another frame, then see the `frame` or `frameName` properties instead.

You should only use `loadTexture` if you want to replace the base texture entirely.

Calling this method causes a WebGL texture update, so use sparingly or in low-intensity portions of your game, or if you know the new texture is already on the GPU.

params.description: This is the image or texture used by the Sprite during rendering. It can be a string which is a reference to the Cache Image entry, or an instance of a RenderTexture, BitmapData, Video or PIXI.Texture.
params.name: key

params.description: If this Sprite is using part of a sprite sheet or texture atlas you can specify the exact frame to use by giving a string or numeric index.
params.name: frame

params.description: If an animation is already playing on this Sprite you can choose to stop it or let it carry on playing.
params.name: stopAnimation

name: setFrame
description:
Sets the texture frame the Game Object uses for rendering.

This is primarily an internal method used by `loadTexture`, but is exposed for the use of plugins and custom classes.

params.description: The Frame to be used by the texture.
params.name: frame

name: resizeFrame
description:
Resizes the Frame dimensions that the Game Object uses for rendering.

You shouldn't normally need to ever call this, but in the case of special texture types such as Video or BitmapData
it can be useful to adjust the dimensions directly in this way.

params.description: The parent texture object that caused the resize, i.e. a Phaser.Video object.
params.name: parent

params.description: The new width of the texture.
params.name: width

params.description: The new height of the texture.
params.name: height

name: resetFrame
description: Resets the texture frame dimensions that the Game Object uses for rendering.

name: overlap
description:
Checks to see if the bounds of this Game Object overlaps with the bounds of the given Display Object,
which can be a Sprite, Image, TileSprite or anything that extends those such as Button or provides a `getBounds` method and result.

This check ignores the `hitArea` property if set and runs a `getBounds` comparison on both objects to determine the result.

Therefore it's relatively expensive to use in large quantities, i.e. with lots of Sprites at a high frequency.
It should be fine for low-volume testing where physics isn't required.

params.description: The display object to check against.
params.name: displayObject

returns.description: True if the bounds of this Game Object intersects at any point with the bounds of the given display object.

name: setScaleMinMax
description:
Sets the scaleMin and scaleMax values. These values are used to limit how far this Game Object will scale based on its parent.

For example if this Game Object has a `minScale` value of 1 and its parent has a `scale` value of 0.5, the 0.5 will be ignored
and the scale value of 1 will be used, as the parents scale is lower than the minimum scale this Game Object should adhere to.

By setting these values you can carefully control how Game Objects deal with responsive scaling.

If only one parameter is given then that value will be used for both scaleMin and scaleMax:
`setScaleMinMax(1)` = scaleMin.x, scaleMin.y, scaleMax.x and scaleMax.y all = 1

If only two parameters are given the first is set as scaleMin.x and y and the second as scaleMax.x and y:
`setScaleMinMax(0.5, 2)` = scaleMin.x and y = 0.5 and scaleMax.x and y = 2

If you wish to set `scaleMin` with different values for x and y then either modify Game Object.scaleMin directly,
or pass `null` for the `maxX` and `maxY` parameters.

Call `setScaleMinMax(null)` to clear all previously set values.

params.description: The minimum horizontal scale value this Game Object can scale down to.
params.name: minX

params.description: The minimum vertical scale value this Game Object can scale down to.
params.name: minY

params.description: The maximum horizontal scale value this Game Object can scale up to.
params.name: maxX

params.description: The maximum vertical scale value this Game Object can scale up to.
params.name: maxY

name: existing
description: Adds an existing display object to the game world.

params.description: An instance of Phaser.Sprite, Phaser.Button or any other display object.
params.name: object

returns.description: The child that was added to the World.

name: image
description:
Create a new `Image` object.

An Image is a light-weight object you can use to display anything that doesn't need physics or animation.

It can still rotate, scale, crop and receive input events.
This makes it perfect for logos, backgrounds, simple buttons and other non-Sprite graphics.

params.description: The x coordinate of the Image. The coordinate is relative to any parent container this Image may be in.
params.name: x

params.description: The y coordinate of the Image. The coordinate is relative to any parent container this Image may be in.
params.name: y

params.description: The image used as a texture by this display object during rendering. If a string Phaser will get for an entry in the Image Cache. Or it can be an instance of a RenderTexture, BitmapData, Video or PIXI.Texture.
params.name: key

params.description: If a Texture Atlas or Sprite Sheet is used this allows you to specify the frame to be used. Use either an integer for a Frame ID or a string for a frame name.
params.name: frame

params.description: Optional Group to add the object to. If not specified it will be added to the World group.
params.name: group

returns.description: The newly created Image object.

name: sprite
description:
Create a new Sprite with specific position and sprite sheet key.

At its most basic a Sprite consists of a set of coordinates and a texture that is used when rendered.
They also contain additional properties allowing for physics motion (via Sprite.body), input handling (via Sprite.input),
events (via Sprite.events), animation (via Sprite.animations), camera culling and more. Please see the Examples for use cases.

params.description: The x coordinate of the sprite. The coordinate is relative to any parent container this sprite may be in.
params.name: x

params.description: The y coordinate of the sprite. The coordinate is relative to any parent container this sprite may be in.
params.name: y

params.description: The image used as a texture by this display object during rendering. If a string Phaser will get for an entry in the Image Cache. Or it can be an instance of a RenderTexture, BitmapData, Video or PIXI.Texture.
params.name: key

params.description: If a Texture Atlas or Sprite Sheet is used this allows you to specify the frame to be used. Use either an integer for a Frame ID or a string for a frame name.
params.name: frame

params.description: Optional Group to add the object to. If not specified it will be added to the World group.
params.name: group

returns.description: The newly created Sprite object.

name: creature
description:
Create a new Creature Animation object.

Creature is a custom Game Object used in conjunction with the Creature Runtime libraries by Kestrel Moon Studios.

It allows you to display animated Game Objects that were created with the [Creature Automated Animation Tool](http://www.kestrelmoon.com/creature/).

Note 1: You can only use Phaser.Creature objects in WebGL enabled games. They do not work in Canvas mode games.

Note 2: You must use a build of Phaser that includes the CreatureMeshBone.js runtime and gl-matrix.js, or have them
loaded before your Phaser game boots.

See the Phaser custom build process for more details.

params.description: The x coordinate of the creature. The coordinate is relative to any parent container this creature may be in.
params.name: x

params.description: The y coordinate of the creature. The coordinate is relative to any parent container this creature may be in.
params.name: y

params.description: The image used as a texture by this creature object during rendering. If a string Phaser will get for an entry in the Image Cache. Or it can be an instance of a PIXI.Texture.
params.name: key

params.description: Optional Group to add the object to. If not specified it will be added to the World group.
params.name: group

returns.description: The newly created Sprite object.

name: tween
description:
Create a tween on a specific object.

The object can be any JavaScript object or Phaser object such as Sprite.

params.description: Object the tween will be run on.
params.name: object

returns.description: The newly created Phaser.Tween object.

name: group
description: A Group is a container for display objects that allows for fast pooling, recycling and collision checks.

params.description: The parent Group or DisplayObjectContainer that will hold this group, if any. If set to null the Group won't be added to the display list. If undefined it will be added to World by default.
params.name: parent

params.description: A name for this Group. Not used internally but useful for debugging.
params.name: name

params.description: If set to true this Group will be added directly to the Game.Stage instead of Game.World.
params.name: addToStage

params.description: If true all Sprites created with `Group.create` or `Group.createMulitple` will have a physics body created on them. Change the body type with physicsBodyType.
params.name: enableBody

params.description: If enableBody is true this is the type of physics body that is created on new Sprites. Phaser.Physics.ARCADE, Phaser.Physics.P2, Phaser.Physics.NINJA, etc.
params.name: physicsBodyType

returns.description: The newly created Group.

name: physicsGroup
description:
A Group is a container for display objects that allows for fast pooling, recycling and collision checks.

A Physics Group is the same as an ordinary Group except that is has enableBody turned on by default, so any Sprites it creates
are automatically given a physics body.

params.description: If enableBody is true this is the type of physics body that is created on new Sprites. Phaser.Physics.ARCADE, Phaser.Physics.P2, Phaser.Physics.NINJA, etc.
params.name: physicsBodyType

params.description: The parent Group or DisplayObjectContainer that will hold this group, if any. If set to null the Group won't be added to the display list. If undefined it will be added to World by default.
params.name: parent

params.description: A name for this Group. Not used internally but useful for debugging.
params.name: name

params.description: If set to true this Group will be added directly to the Game.Stage instead of Game.World.
params.name: addToStage

returns.description: The newly created Group.

name: spriteBatch
description:
A SpriteBatch is a really fast version of a Phaser Group built solely for speed.
Use when you need a lot of sprites or particles all sharing the same texture.
The speed gains are specifically for WebGL. In Canvas mode you won't see any real difference.

params.description: The parent Group that will hold this Sprite Batch. Set to `undefined` or `null` to add directly to game.world.
params.name: parent

params.description: A name for this Sprite Batch. Not used internally but useful for debugging.
params.name: name

params.description: If set to true this Sprite Batch will be added directly to the Game.Stage instead of the parent.
params.name: addToStage

returns.description: The newly created Sprite Batch.

name: audio
description: Creates a new Sound object.

params.description: The Game.cache key of the sound that this object will use.
params.name: key

params.description: The volume at which the sound will be played.
params.name: volume

params.description: Whether or not the sound will loop.
params.name: loop

params.description: Controls if the created Sound object will connect to the master gainNode of the SoundManager when running under WebAudio.
params.name: connect

returns.description: The newly created sound object.

name: sound
description: Creates a new Sound object.

params.description: The Game.cache key of the sound that this object will use.
params.name: key

params.description: The volume at which the sound will be played.
params.name: volume

params.description: Whether or not the sound will loop.
params.name: loop

params.description: Controls if the created Sound object will connect to the master gainNode of the SoundManager when running under WebAudio.
params.name: connect

returns.description: The newly created sound object.

name: audioSprite
description: Creates a new AudioSprite object.

params.description: The Game.cache key of the sound that this object will use.
params.name: key

returns.description: The newly created AudioSprite object.

name: tileSprite
description: Creates a new TileSprite object.

params.description: The x coordinate of the TileSprite. The coordinate is relative to any parent container this TileSprite may be in.
params.name: x

params.description: The y coordinate of the TileSprite. The coordinate is relative to any parent container this TileSprite may be in.
params.name: y

params.description: The width of the TileSprite.
params.name: width

params.description: The height of the TileSprite.
params.name: height

params.description: The image used as a texture by this display object during rendering. If a string Phaser will get for an entry in the Image Cache. Or it can be an instance of a RenderTexture, BitmapData, Video or PIXI.Texture.
params.name: key

params.description: If a Texture Atlas or Sprite Sheet is used this allows you to specify the frame to be used. Use either an integer for a Frame ID or a string for a frame name.
params.name: frame

params.description: Optional Group to add the object to. If not specified it will be added to the World group.
params.name: group

returns.description: The newly created TileSprite object.

name: rope
description:
Creates a new Rope object.

Example usage: https://github.com/codevinsky/phaser-rope-demo/blob/master/dist/demo.js

params.description: The x coordinate of the Rope. The coordinate is relative to any parent container this rope may be in.
params.name: x

params.description: The y coordinate of the Rope. The coordinate is relative to any parent container this rope may be in.
params.name: y

params.description: The image used as a texture by this display object during rendering. If a string Phaser will get for an entry in the Image Cache. Or it can be an instance of a RenderTexture, BitmapData, Video or PIXI.Texture.
params.name: key

params.description: If a Texture Atlas or Sprite Sheet is used this allows you to specify the frame to be used. Use either an integer for a Frame ID or a string for a frame name.
params.name: frame

params.description: An array of {Phaser.Point}.
params.name: points

params.description: Optional Group to add the object to. If not specified it will be added to the World group.
params.name: group

returns.description: The newly created Rope object.

name: text
description: Creates a new Text object.

params.description: The x coordinate of the Text. The coordinate is relative to any parent container this text may be in.
params.name: x

params.description: The y coordinate of the Text. The coordinate is relative to any parent container this text may be in.
params.name: y

params.description: The text string that will be displayed.
params.name: text

params.description: The style object containing style attributes like font, font size , etc.
params.name: style

params.description: Optional Group to add the object to. If not specified it will be added to the World group.
params.name: group

returns.description: The newly created text object.

name: button
description: Creates a new Button object.

params.description: The x coordinate of the Button. The coordinate is relative to any parent container this button may be in.
params.name: x

params.description: The y coordinate of the Button. The coordinate is relative to any parent container this button may be in.
params.name: y

params.description: The image key as defined in the Game.Cache to use as the texture for this button.
params.name: key

params.description: The function to call when this button is pressed
params.name: callback

params.description: The context in which the callback will be called (usually 'this')
params.name: callbackContext

params.description: This is the frame or frameName that will be set when this button is in an over state. Give either a number to use a frame ID or a string for a frame name.
params.name: overFrame

Create a new Emitter.

A particle emitter can be used for one-time explosions or for
continuous effects like rain and fire. All it really does is launch Particle objects out
at set intervals, and fixes their positions and velocities accordingly.

name: retroFont
description:
Create a new RetroFont object.

A RetroFont can be used as a texture for an Image or Sprite and optionally add it to the Cache.
A RetroFont uses a bitmap which contains fixed with characters for the font set. You use character spacing to define the set.
If you need variable width character support then use a BitmapText object instead. The main difference between a RetroFont and a BitmapText
is that a RetroFont creates a single texture that you can apply to a game object, where-as a BitmapText creates one Sprite object per letter of text.
The texture can be asssigned or one or multiple images/sprites, but note that the text the RetroFont uses will be shared across them all,
i.e. if you need each Image to have different text in it, then you need to create multiple RetroFont objects.

params.description: The key of the image in the Game.Cache that the RetroFont will use.
params.name: font

params.description: The width of each character in the font set.
params.name: characterWidth

params.description: The height of each character in the font set.
params.name: characterHeight

params.description: The characters used in the font set, in display order. You can use the TEXT_SET consts for common font set arrangements.
params.name: chars

params.description: The number of characters per row in the font set.
params.name: charsPerRow

params.description: If the characters in the font set have horizontal spacing between them set the required amount here.
params.name: xSpacing

params.description: If the characters in the font set have vertical spacing between them set the required amount here.
params.name: ySpacing

params.description: If the font set doesn't start at the top left of the given image, specify the X coordinate offset here.
params.name: xOffset

params.description: If the font set doesn't start at the top left of the given image, specify the Y coordinate offset here.
params.name: yOffset

returns.description: The newly created RetroFont texture which can be applied to an Image or Sprite.

name: bitmapText
description:
Create a new BitmapText object.

BitmapText objects work by taking a texture file and an XML file that describes the font structure.
It then generates a new Sprite object for each letter of the text, proportionally spaced out and aligned to
match the font structure.

BitmapText objects are less flexible than Text objects, in that they have less features such as shadows, fills and the ability
to use Web Fonts. However you trade this flexibility for pure rendering speed. You can also create visually compelling BitmapTexts by
processing the font texture in an image editor first, applying fills and any other effects required.

To create multi-line text insert \r, \n or \r\n escape codes into the text string.

To create a BitmapText data files you can use:

BMFont (Windows, free): http://www.angelcode.com/products/bmfont/
Glyph Designer (OS X, commercial): http://www.71squared.com/en/glyphdesigner
Littera (Web-based, free): http://kvazars.com/littera/

params.description: X coordinate to display the BitmapText object at.
params.name: x

params.description: Y coordinate to display the BitmapText object at.
params.name: y

params.description: The key of the BitmapText as stored in Phaser.Cache.
params.name: font

params.description: The text that will be rendered. This can also be set later via BitmapText.text.
params.name: text

params.description: The size the font will be rendered at in pixels.
params.name: size

params.description: Optional Group to add the object to. If not specified it will be added to the World group.
params.name: group

returns.description: The newly created bitmapText object.

name: tilemap
description:
Creates a new Phaser.Tilemap object.

The map can either be populated with data from a Tiled JSON file or from a CSV file.
To do this pass the Cache key as the first parameter. When using Tiled data you need only provide the key.
When using CSV data you must provide the key and the tileWidth and tileHeight parameters.
If creating a blank tilemap to be populated later, you can either specify no parameters at all and then use `Tilemap.create` or pass the map and tile dimensions here.
Note that all Tilemaps use a base tile size to calculate dimensions from, but that a TilemapLayer may have its own unique tile size that overrides it.

params.description: The key of the tilemap data as stored in the Cache. If you're creating a blank map either leave this parameter out or pass `null`.
params.name: key

params.name: tileHeight

params.name: width

params.description: The height of the map in tiles. If this map is created from Tiled or CSV data you don't need to specify this.
params.name: height

returns.description: The newly created tilemap object.

name: image

An Image is a light-weight object you can use to display anything that doesn't need physics or animation.

If the TileSprite has a physics body that too is reset.

name: onInputDownHandler
description: Internal function that handles input events.

params.description: The Button that the event occurred on.
params.name: sprite

params.description: The Pointer that activated the Button.
params.name: pointer

name: onInputUpHandler
description: Internal function that handles input events.

params.description: The Button that the event occurred on.
params.name: sprite

params.description: The Pointer that activated the Button.
params.name: pointer

name: update
description: Updates the Particle scale or alpha if autoScale and autoAlpha are set.

name: onEmit
description: Called by the Emitter when this particle is emitted. Left empty for you to over-ride as required.

name: setAlphaData
description: Called by the Emitter if autoAlpha has been enabled. Passes over the alpha ease data and resets the alpha counter.

name: setScaleData
description: Called by the Emitter if autoScale has been enabled. Passes over the scale ease data and resets the scale counter.

name: reset
description:
Resets the Particle. This places the Particle at the given x/y world coordinates and then
sets alive, exists, visible and renderable all to true. Also resets the outOfBounds state and health values.
If the Particle has a physics body that too is reset.

params.description: The x coordinate (in world space) to position the Particle at.
params.name: x

params.description: The y coordinate (in world space) to position the Particle at.
params.name: y

params.description: The health to give the Particle.
params.name: health

returns.description: (Phaser.Particle) This instance.

name: move
description:
Shifts the contents of this BitmapData by the distances given.

The image will wrap-around the edges on all sides.

params.description: The amount of pixels to horizontally shift the canvas by. Use a negative value to shift to the left, positive to the right.
params.name: x

params.description: The amount of pixels to vertically shift the canvas by. Use a negative value to shift up, positive to shift down.
params.name: y

returns.description: This BitmapData object for method chaining.

name: moveH
description:
Shifts the contents of this BitmapData horizontally.

The image will wrap-around the sides.

params.description: The amount of pixels to horizontally shift the canvas by. Use a negative value to shift to the left, positive to the right.
params.name: distance

returns.description: This BitmapData object for method chaining.

name: moveV
description:
Shifts the contents of this BitmapData vertically.

The image will wrap-around the sides.

params.description: The amount of pixels to vertically shift the canvas by. Use a negative value to shift up, positive to shift down.
params.name: distance

returns.description: This BitmapData object for method chaining.

name: add
description:
Updates the given objects so that they use this BitmapData as their texture.
This will replace any texture they will currently have set.

params.description: Either a single Sprite/Image or an Array of Sprites/Images.
params.name: object

returns.description: This BitmapData object for method chaining.

name: load
description:
Takes the given Game Object, resizes this BitmapData to match it and then draws it into this BitmapDatas canvas, ready for further processing.
The source game object is not modified by this operation.
If the source object uses a texture as part of a Texture Atlas or Sprite Sheet, only the current frame will be used for sizing.
If a string is given it will assume it's a cache key and look in Phaser.Cache for an image key matching the string.

params.description: The object that will be used to populate this BitmapData. If you give a string it will try and find the Image in the Game.Cache first.
params.name: source

returns.description: This BitmapData object for method chaining.

name: clear
description:
Clears the BitmapData context using a clearRect.

You can optionally define the area to clear.
If the arguments are left empty it will clear the entire canvas.

params.description: The x coordinate of the top-left of the area to clear.
params.name: x

params.description: The y coordinate of the top-left of the area to clear.
params.name: y

params.description: The width of the area to clear. If undefined it will use BitmapData.width.
params.name: width

params.description: The height of the area to clear. If undefined it will use BitmapData.height.
params.name: height

returns.description: This BitmapData object for method chaining.

name: cls
description: Clears the BitmapData context using a clearRect.

name: fill
description: Fills the BitmapData with the given color.

params.description: The red color value, between 0 and 0xFF (255).
params.name: r

params.description: The green color value, between 0 and 0xFF (255).
params.name: g

params.description: The blue color value, between 0 and 0xFF (255).
params.name: b

params.description: The alpha color value, between 0 and 1.
params.name: a

returns.description: This BitmapData object for method chaining.

name: generateTexture
description:
Creates a new Image element by converting this BitmapDatas canvas into a dataURL.

The image is then stored in the image Cache using the key given.

Finally a PIXI.Texture is created based on the image and returned.

You can apply the texture to a sprite or any other supporting object by using either the
key or the texture. First call generateTexture:

`var texture = bitmapdata.generateTexture('ball');`

Then you can either apply the texture to a sprite:

`game.add.sprite(0, 0, texture);`

or by using the string based key:

`game.add.sprite(0, 0, 'ball');`

params.description: The key which will be used to store the image in the Cache.
params.name: key

returns.description: The newly generated texture.

name: resize
description: Resizes the BitmapData. This changes the size of the underlying canvas and refreshes the buffer.

returns.description: This BitmapData object for method chaining.

name: update
description:
This re-creates the BitmapData.imageData from the current context.
It then re-builds the ArrayBuffer, the data Uint8ClampedArray reference and the pixels Int32Array.
If not given the dimensions defaults to the full size of the context.

params.description: The x coordinate of the top-left of the image data area to grab from.
params.name: x

params.description: The y coordinate of the top-left of the image data area to grab from.
params.name: y

params.description: The width of the image data area.
params.name: width

params.description: The height of the image data area.
params.name: height

returns.description: This BitmapData object for method chaining.

name: processPixelRGB
description:
Scans through the area specified in this BitmapData and sends a color object for every pixel to the given callback.
The callback will be sent a color object with 6 properties: `{ r: number, g: number, b: number, a: number, color: number, rgba: string }`.
Where r, g, b and a are integers between 0 and 255 representing the color component values for red, green, blue and alpha.
The `color` property is an Int32 of the full color. Note the endianess of this will change per system.
The `rgba` property is a CSS style rgba() string which can be used with context.fillStyle calls, among others.
The callback will also be sent the pixels x and y coordinates respectively.
The callback must return either `false`, in which case no change will be made to the pixel, or a new color object.
If a new color object is returned the pixel will be set to the r, g, b and a color values given within it.

params.description: The callback that will be sent each pixel color object to be processed.
params.name: callback

params.description: The context under which the callback will be called.
params.name: callbackContext

params.description: The x coordinate of the top-left of the region to process from.
params.name: x

params.description: The y coordinate of the top-left of the region to process from.
params.name: y

params.description: The width of the region to process.
params.name: width

params.description: The height of the region to process.
params.name: height

returns.description: This BitmapData object for method chaining.

name: processPixel
description:
Scans through the area specified in this BitmapData and sends the color for every pixel to the given callback along with its x and y coordinates.
Whatever value the callback returns is set as the new color for that pixel, unless it returns the same color, in which case it's skipped.
Note that the format of the color received will be different depending on if the system is big or little endian.
It is expected that your callback will deal with endianess. If you'd rather Phaser did it then use processPixelRGB instead.
The callback will also be sent the pixels x and y coordinates respectively.

params.description: The callback that will be sent each pixel color to be processed.
params.name: callback

params.description: The context under which the callback will be called.
params.name: callbackContext

params.description: The x coordinate of the top-left of the region to process from.
params.name: x

params.description: The y coordinate of the top-left of the region to process from.
params.name: y

params.description: The width of the region to process.
params.name: width

params.description: The height of the region to process.
params.name: height

returns.description: This BitmapData object for method chaining.

name: replaceRGB
description:
Replaces all pixels matching one color with another. The color values are given as two sets of RGBA values.
An optional region parameter controls if the replacement happens in just a specific area of the BitmapData or the entire thing.

params.description: The red color value to be replaced. Between 0 and 255.
params.name: r1

params.description: The green color value to be replaced. Between 0 and 255.
params.name: g1

params.description: The blue color value to be replaced. Between 0 and 255.
params.name: b1

params.description: The alpha color value to be replaced. Between 0 and 255.
params.name: a1

params.description: The red color value that is the replacement color. Between 0 and 255.
params.name: r2

params.description: The green color value that is the replacement color. Between 0 and 255.
params.name: g2

params.description: The blue color value that is the replacement color. Between 0 and 255.
params.name: b2

params.description: The alpha color value that is the replacement color. Between 0 and 255.
params.name: a2

params.description: The area to perform the search over. If not given it will replace over the whole BitmapData.
params.name: region

returns.description: This BitmapData object for method chaining.

name: setHSL
description: Sets the hue, saturation and lightness values on every pixel in the given region, or the whole BitmapData if no region was specified.

params.description: The hue, in the range 0 - 1.
params.name: h

params.description: The saturation, in the range 0 - 1.
params.name: s

params.description: The lightness, in the range 0 - 1.
params.name: l

params.description: The area to perform the operation on. If not given it will run over the whole BitmapData.
params.name: region

returns.description: This BitmapData object for method chaining.

name: shiftHSL
description:
Shifts any or all of the hue, saturation and lightness values on every pixel in the given region, or the whole BitmapData if no region was specified.
Shifting will add the given value onto the current h, s and l values, not replace them.
The hue is wrapped to keep it within the range 0 to 1. Saturation and lightness are clamped to not exceed 1.

params.description: The amount to shift the hue by.
params.name: h

params.description: The amount to shift the saturation by.
params.name: s

params.description: The amount to shift the lightness by.
params.name: l

params.description: The area to perform the operation on. If not given it will run over the whole BitmapData.
params.name: region

returns.description: This BitmapData object for method chaining.

name: setPixel32
description: Sets the color of the given pixel to the specified red, green, blue and alpha values.

params.description: The x coordinate of the pixel to be set. Must lay within the dimensions of this BitmapData.
params.name: x

params.description: The y coordinate of the pixel to be set. Must lay within the dimensions of this BitmapData.
params.name: y

params.description: The red color value, between 0 and 0xFF (255).
params.name: red

params.description: The green color value, between 0 and 0xFF (255).
params.name: green

params.description: The blue color value, between 0 and 0xFF (255).
params.name: blue

params.description: The alpha color value, between 0 and 0xFF (255).
params.name: alpha

params.description: If `true` the context.putImageData will be called and the dirty flag set.
params.name: immediate

returns.description: This BitmapData object for method chaining.

name: setPixel
description: Sets the color of the given pixel to the specified red, green and blue values.

params.description: The x coordinate of the pixel to be set. Must lay within the dimensions of this BitmapData.
params.name: x

params.description: The y coordinate of the pixel to be set. Must lay within the dimensions of this BitmapData.
params.name: y

params.description: The red color value, between 0 and 0xFF (255).
params.name: red

params.description: The green color value, between 0 and 0xFF (255).
params.name: green

params.description: The blue color value, between 0 and 0xFF (255).
params.name: blue

params.description: The alpha color value, between 0 and 0xFF (255).
params.name: alpha

params.description: If `true` the context.putImageData will be called and the dirty flag set.
params.name: immediate

returns.description: This BitmapData object for method chaining.

name: getPixel
description:
Get the color of a specific pixel in the context into a color object.
If you have drawn anything to the BitmapData since it was created you must call BitmapData.update to refresh the array buffer,
otherwise this may return out of date color values, or worse - throw a run-time error as it tries to access an array element that doesn't exist.

params.description: The x coordinate of the pixel to be set. Must lay within the dimensions of this BitmapData.
params.name: x

params.description: The y coordinate of the pixel to be set. Must lay within the dimensions of this BitmapData.
params.name: y

params.description: An object into which 4 properties will be created: r, g, b and a. If not provided a new object will be created.
params.name: out

returns.description: An object with the red, green, blue and alpha values set in the r, g, b and a properties.

name: getPixel32
description:
Get the color of a specific pixel including its alpha value.
If you have drawn anything to the BitmapData since it was created you must call BitmapData.update to refresh the array buffer,
otherwise this may return out of date color values, or worse - throw a run-time error as it tries to access an array element that doesn't exist.
Note that on little-endian systems the format is 0xAABBGGRR and on big-endian the format is 0xRRGGBBAA.

params.description: The x coordinate of the pixel to be set. Must lay within the dimensions of this BitmapData.
params.name: x

params.description: The y coordinate of the pixel to be set. Must lay within the dimensions of this BitmapData.
params.name: y

returns.description: A native color value integer (format: 0xAARRGGBB)

name: getPixelRGB
description:
Get the color of a specific pixel including its alpha value as a color object containing r,g,b,a and rgba properties.
If you have drawn anything to the BitmapData since it was created you must call BitmapData.update to refresh the array buffer,
otherwise this may return out of date color values, or worse - throw a run-time error as it tries to access an array element that doesn't exist.

params.description: The x coordinate of the pixel to be set. Must lay within the dimensions of this BitmapData.
params.name: x

params.description: The y coordinate of the pixel to be set. Must lay within the dimensions of this BitmapData.
params.name: y

params.description: An object into which 3 properties will be created: r, g and b. If not provided a new object will be created.
params.name: out

params.description: Also convert the rgb values into hsl?
params.name: hsl

params.description: Also convert the rgb values into hsv?
params.name: hsv

returns.description: An object with the red, green and blue values set in the r, g and b properties.

name: getPixels
description: Gets all the pixels from the region specified by the given Rectangle object.

params.description: The Rectangle region to get.
params.name: rect

returns.description: Returns a ImageData object containing a Uint8ClampedArray data property.

name: getFirstPixel
description:
Scans the BitmapData, pixel by pixel, until it encounters a pixel that isn't transparent (i.e. has an alpha value > 0).
It then stops scanning and returns an object containing the color of the pixel in r, g and b properties and the location in the x and y properties.

The direction parameter controls from which direction it should start the scan:

0 = top to bottom
1 = bottom to top
2 = left to right
3 = right to left

params.description: The direction in which to scan for the first pixel. 0 = top to bottom, 1 = bottom to top, 2 = left to right and 3 = right to left.
params.name: direction

returns.description: Returns an object containing the color of the pixel in the `r`, `g` and `b` properties and the location in the `x` and `y` properties.

name: getBounds
description:
Scans the BitmapData and calculates the bounds. This is a rectangle that defines the extent of all non-transparent pixels.
The rectangle returned will extend from the top-left of the image to the bottom-right, excluding transparent pixels.

params.description: If provided this Rectangle object will be populated with the bounds, otherwise a new object will be created.
params.name: rect

returns.description: A Rectangle whose dimensions encompass the full extent of non-transparent pixels in this BitmapData.

name: addToWorld
description: Creates a new Phaser.Image object, assigns this BitmapData to be its texture, adds it to the world then returns it.

params.description: The x coordinate to place the Image at.
params.name: x

params.description: The y coordinate to place the Image at.
params.name: y

params.description: Set the x anchor point of the Image. A value between 0 and 1, where 0 is the top-left and 1 is bottom-right.
params.name: anchorX

params.description: Set the y anchor point of the Image. A value between 0 and 1, where 0 is the top-left and 1 is bottom-right.
params.name: anchorY

params.description: The horizontal scale factor of the Image. A value of 1 means no scaling. 2 would be twice the size, and so on.
params.name: scaleX

params.description: The vertical scale factor of the Image. A value of 1 means no scaling. 2 would be twice the size, and so on.
params.name: scaleY

returns.description: The newly added Image object.

name: copy
description:
Copies a rectangular area from the source object to this BitmapData. If you give `null` as the source it will copy from itself.
You can optionally resize, translate, rotate, scale, alpha or blend as it's drawn.
All rotation, scaling and drawing takes place around the regions center point by default, but can be changed with the anchor parameters.
Note that the source image can also be this BitmapData, which can create some interesting effects.

This method has a lot of parameters for maximum control.
You can use the more friendly methods like `copyRect` and `draw` to avoid having to remember them all.

params.description: The source to copy from. If you give a string it will try and find the Image in the Game.Cache first. This is quite expensive so try to provide the image itself.
params.name: source

params.description: The x coordinate representing the top-left of the region to copy from the source image.
params.name: x

params.description: The y coordinate representing the top-left of the region to copy from the source image.
params.name: y

params.description: The width of the region to copy from the source image. If not specified it will use the full source image width.
params.name: width

params.description: The height of the region to copy from the source image. If not specified it will use the full source image height.
params.name: height

params.description: The x coordinate to translate to before drawing. If not specified it will default to the `x` parameter. If `null` and `source` is a Display Object, it will default to `source.x`.
params.name: tx

params.description: The y coordinate to translate to before drawing. If not specified it will default to the `y` parameter. If `null` and `source` is a Display Object, it will default to `source.y`.
params.name: ty

params.description: The new width of the block being copied. If not specified it will default to the `width` parameter.
params.name: newWidth

params.description: The new height of the block being copied. If not specified it will default to the `height` parameter.
params.name: newHeight

params.description: The angle in radians to rotate the block to before drawing. Rotation takes place around the center by default, but can be changed with the `anchor` parameters.
params.name: rotate

params.description: The anchor point around which the block is rotated and scaled. A value between 0 and 1, where 0 is the top-left and 1 is bottom-right.
params.name: anchorX

params.description: The anchor point around which the block is rotated and scaled. A value between 0 and 1, where 0 is the top-left and 1 is bottom-right.
params.name: anchorY

params.description: The horizontal scale factor of the block. A value of 1 means no scaling. 2 would be twice the size, and so on.
params.name: scaleX

params.description: The vertical scale factor of the block. A value of 1 means no scaling. 2 would be twice the size, and so on.
params.name: scaleY

params.description: The alpha that will be set on the context before drawing. A value between 0 (fully transparent) and 1, opaque.
params.name: alpha

params.description: The composite blend mode that will be used when drawing. The default is no blend mode at all. This is a Canvas globalCompositeOperation value such as 'lighter' or 'xor'.
params.name: blendMode

params.description: Should the x and y values be rounded to integers before drawing? This prevents anti-aliasing in some instances.
params.name: roundPx

returns.description: This BitmapData object for method chaining.

name: copyRect
description: Copies the area defined by the Rectangle parameter from the source image to this BitmapData at the given location.

params.description: The Image to copy from. If you give a string it will try and find the Image in the Game.Cache.
params.name: source

params.description: The Rectangle region to copy from the source image.
params.name: area

params.description: The destination x coordinate to copy the image to.
params.name: x

params.description: The destination y coordinate to copy the image to.
params.name: y

params.description: The alpha that will be set on the context before drawing. A value between 0 (fully transparent) and 1, opaque.
params.name: alpha

params.description: The composite blend mode that will be used when drawing. The default is no blend mode at all. This is a Canvas globalCompositeOperation value such as 'lighter' or 'xor'.
params.name: blendMode

params.description: Should the x and y values be rounded to integers before drawing? This prevents anti-aliasing in some instances.
params.name: roundPx

returns.description: This BitmapData object for method chaining.

name: draw
description:
Draws the given Phaser.Sprite, Phaser.Image or Phaser.Text to this BitmapData at the coordinates specified.
You can use the optional width and height values to 'stretch' the sprite as it is drawn. This uses drawImage stretching, not scaling.
When drawing it will take into account the Sprites rotation, scale and alpha values.

params.description: The Sprite, Image or Text object to draw onto this BitmapData.
params.name: source

params.description: The x coordinate to translate to before drawing. If not specified it will default to `source.x`.
params.name: x

params.description: The y coordinate to translate to before drawing. If not specified it will default to `source.y`.
params.name: y

params.description: The new width of the Sprite being copied. If not specified it will default to `source.width`.
params.name: width

params.description: The new height of the Sprite being copied. If not specified it will default to `source.height`.
params.name: height

params.description: The composite blend mode that will be used when drawing. The default is no blend mode at all. This is a Canvas globalCompositeOperation value such as 'lighter' or 'xor'.
params.name: blendMode

params.description: Should the x and y values be rounded to integers before drawing? This prevents anti-aliasing in some instances.
params.name: roundPx

returns.description: This BitmapData object for method chaining.

name: drawGroup
description:
Draws the immediate children of a Phaser.Group to this BitmapData.
Children are only drawn if they have their `exists` property set to `true`.
The children will be drawn at their `x` and `y` world space coordinates. If this is outside the bounds of the BitmapData they won't be drawn.
When drawing it will take into account the child's rotation, scale and alpha values.
No iteration takes place. Groups nested inside other Groups will not be iterated through.

params.description: The Group to draw onto this BitmapData.
params.name: group

params.description: The composite blend mode that will be used when drawing. The default is no blend mode at all. This is a Canvas globalCompositeOperation value such as 'lighter' or 'xor'.
params.name: blendMode

params.description: Should the x and y values be rounded to integers before drawing? This prevents anti-aliasing in some instances.
params.name: roundPx

returns.description: This BitmapData object for method chaining.

name: shadow
description:
Sets the shadow properties of this BitmapDatas context which will affect all draw operations made to it.
You can cancel an existing shadow by calling this method and passing no parameters.
Note: At the time of writing (October 2014) Chrome still doesn't support shadowBlur used with drawImage.

params.description: The color of the shadow, given in a CSS format, i.e. `#000000` or `rgba(0,0,0,1)`. If `null` or `undefined` the shadow will be reset.
params.name: color

params.description: The amount the shadow will be blurred by. Low values = a crisp shadow, high values = a softer shadow.
params.name: blur

params.description: The horizontal offset of the shadow in pixels.
params.name: x

params.description: The vertical offset of the shadow in pixels.
params.name: y

returns.description: This BitmapData object for method chaining.

name: alphaMask
description: Draws the image onto this BitmapData using an image as an alpha mask.

params.description: The source to copy from. If you give a string it will try and find the Image in the Game.Cache first. This is quite expensive so try to provide the image itself.
params.name: source

params.description: The object to be used as the mask. If you give a string it will try and find the Image in the Game.Cache first. This is quite expensive so try to provide the image itself. If you don't provide a mask it will use this BitmapData as the mask.
params.name: mask

params.description: A Rectangle where x/y define the coordinates to draw the Source image to and width/height define the size.
params.name: sourceRect

params.description: A Rectangle where x/y define the coordinates to draw the Mask image to and width/height define the size.
params.name: maskRect

returns.description: This BitmapData object for method chaining.

name: extract
description:
Scans this BitmapData for all pixels matching the given r,g,b values and then draws them into the given destination BitmapData.
The original BitmapData remains unchanged.
The destination BitmapData must be large enough to receive all of the pixels that are scanned unless the 'resize' parameter is true.
Although the destination BitmapData is returned from this method, it's actually modified directly in place, meaning this call is perfectly valid:
`picture.extract(mask, r, g, b)`
You can specify optional r2, g2, b2 color values. If given the pixel written to the destination bitmap will be of the r2, g2, b2 color.
If not given it will be written as the same color it was extracted. You can provide one or more alternative colors, allowing you to tint
the color during extraction.

params.description: The BitmapData that the extracted pixels will be drawn to.
params.name: destination

params.description: The red color component, in the range 0 - 255.
params.name: r

params.description: The green color component, in the range 0 - 255.
params.name: g

params.description: The blue color component, in the range 0 - 255.
params.name: b

params.description: The alpha color component, in the range 0 - 255 that the new pixel will be drawn at.
params.name: a

params.description: Should the destination BitmapData be resized to match this one before the pixels are copied?
params.name: resize

params.description: An alternative red color component to be written to the destination, in the range 0 - 255.
params.name: r2

params.description: An alternative green color component to be written to the destination, in the range 0 - 255.
params.name: g2

params.description: An alternative blue color component to be written to the destination, in the range 0 - 255.
params.name: b2

returns.description: The BitmapData that the extract pixels were drawn on.

name: rect
description: Draws a filled Rectangle to the BitmapData at the given x, y coordinates and width / height in size.

params.description: The x coordinate of the top-left of the Rectangle.
params.name: x

params.description: The y coordinate of the top-left of the Rectangle.
params.name: y

params.description: The width of the Rectangle.
params.name: width

params.description: The height of the Rectangle.
params.name: height

params.description: If set the context fillStyle will be set to this value before the rect is drawn.
params.name: fillStyle

returns.description: This BitmapData object for method chaining.

name: text
description:
Draws text to the BitmapData in the given font and color.
The default font is 14px Courier, so useful for quickly drawing debug text.
If you need to do a lot of font work to this BitmapData we'd recommend implementing your own text draw method.

params.description: The text to write to the BitmapData.
params.name: text

params.description: The x coordinate of the top-left of the text string.
params.name: x

params.description: The y coordinate of the top-left of the text string.
params.name: y

params.description: The font. This is passed directly to Context.font, so anything that can support, this can.
params.name: font

params.description: The color the text will be drawn in.
params.name: color

params.description: Draw a single pixel black shadow below the text (offset by text.x/y + 1)
params.name: shadow

description:
This function will draw the display object to the RenderTexture.

In versions of Phaser prior to 2.4.0 the second parameter was a Phaser.Point object.
This is now a Matrix allowing you much more control over how the Display Object is rendered.
If you need to replicate the earlier behavior please use Phaser.RenderTexture.renderXY instead.

If you wish for the displayObject to be rendered taking its current scale, rotation and translation into account then either
pass `null`, leave it undefined or pass `displayObject.worldTransform` as the matrix value.

name: setShadow
description:
Sets a drop shadow effect on the Text. You can specify the horizontal and vertical distance of the drop shadow with the `x` and `y` parameters.
The color controls the shade of the shadow (default is black) and can be either an `rgba` or `hex` value.
The blur is the strength of the shadow. A value of zero means a hard shadow, a value of 10 means a very soft shadow.
To remove a shadow already in place you can call this method with no parameters set.

params.description: The shadowOffsetX value in pixels. This is how far offset horizontally the shadow effect will be.
params.name: x

params.description: The shadowOffsetY value in pixels. This is how far offset vertically the shadow effect will be.
params.name: y

params.description: The color of the shadow, as given in CSS rgba or hex format. Set the alpha component to 0 to disable the shadow.
params.name: color

params.description: The shadowBlur value. Make the shadow softer by applying a Gaussian blur to it. A number from 0 (no blur) up to approx. 10 (depending on scene).
params.name: blur

params.description: Apply the drop shadow to the Text stroke (if set).
params.name: shadowStroke

params.description: Apply the drop shadow to the Text fill (if set).
params.name: shadowFill

returns.description: This Text instance.

params.description: The variant of the font (eg. 'small-caps'): overrides the value in `style.font`.
params.name: style.fontVariant

params.description: The weight of the font (eg. 'bold'): overrides the value in `style.font`.
params.name: style.fontWeight

params.description: The size of the font (eg. 32 or '32px'): overrides the value in `style.font`.
params.name: style.fontSize

params.description: A canvas fillstyle that will be used as the background for the whole Text object. Set to `null` to disable.
params.name: style.backgroundColor

params.description: A canvas fillstyle that will be used on the text eg 'red', '#00FF00'.
params.name: style.fill

params.description: Horizontal alignment of each line in multiline text. Can be: 'left', 'center' or 'right'. Does not affect single lines of text (see `textBounds` and `boundsAlignH` for that).
params.name: style.align

params.description: Horizontal alignment of the text within the `textBounds`. Can be: 'left', 'center' or 'right'.
params.name: style.boundsAlignH

params.description: Vertical alignment of the text within the `textBounds`. Can be: 'top', 'middle' or 'bottom'.
params.name: style.boundsAlignV

params.description: A canvas stroke style that will be used on the text stroke eg 'blue', '#FCFF00'.
params.name: style.stroke

params.description: A number that represents the thickness of the stroke. Default is 0 (no stroke).
params.name: style.strokeThickness

params.description: Indicates if word wrap should be used.
params.name: style.wordWrap

params.description: The width in pixels at which text will wrap.
params.name: style.wordWrapWidth

params.description: The size (in pixels) of the tabs, for when text includes tab characters. 0 disables. Can be an array of varying tab sizes, one per tab stop.
params.name: style.tabs

params.name: state

name: clearColors
description: Clears any text fill or stroke colors that were set by `addColor` or `addStrokeColor`.

returns.description: This Text instance.

name: addColor
description:
Set specific colors for certain characters within the Text.

It works by taking a color value, which is a typical HTML string such as `#ff0000` or `rgb(255,0,0)` and a position.
The position value is the index of the character in the Text string to start applying this color to.
Once set the color remains in use until either another color or the end of the string is encountered.
For example if the Text was `Photon Storm` and you did `Text.addColor('#ffff00', 6)` it would color in the word `Storm` in yellow.

If you wish to change the stroke color see addStrokeColor instead.

params.description: A canvas fillstyle that will be used on the text eg `red`, `#00FF00`, `rgba()`.
params.name: color

params.description: The index of the character in the string to start applying this color value from.
params.name: position

returns.description: This Text instance.

name: addStrokeColor
description:
Set specific stroke colors for certain characters within the Text.

It works by taking a color value, which is a typical HTML string such as `#ff0000` or `rgb(255,0,0)` and a position.
The position value is the index of the character in the Text string to start applying this color to.
Once set the color remains in use until either another color or the end of the string is encountered.
For example if the Text was `Photon Storm` and you did `Text.addColor('#ffff00', 6)` it would color in the word `Storm` in yellow.

This has no effect if stroke is disabled or has a thickness of 0.

If you wish to change the text fill color see addColor instead.

params.description: A canvas fillstyle that will be used on the text stroke eg `red`, `#00FF00`, `rgba()`.
params.name: color

params.description: The index of the character in the string to start applying this color value from.
params.name: position

returns.description: This Text instance.

name: setText
description:
The text to be displayed by this Text object.
Use a \n to insert a carriage return and split the text.

params.name: text

returns.description: This Text instance.

name: parseList
description:
Converts the given array into a tab delimited string and then updates this Text object.
This is mostly used when you want to display external data using tab stops.

The array can be either single or multi dimensional depending on the result you need:

`[ 'a', 'b', 'c' ]` would convert in to `"a\tb\tc"`.

Where as:

`[
     [ 'a', 'b', 'c' ],
     [ 'd', 'e', 'f']
]`

would convert in to: `"a\tb\tc\nd\te\tf"`

params.description: The array of data to convert into a string.
params.name: list

returns.description: This Text instance.

name: setTextBounds
description:
The Text Bounds is a rectangular region that you control the dimensions of into which the Text object itself is positioned,
regardless of the number of lines in the text, the font size or any other attribute.

Alignment is controlled via the properties `boundsAlignH` and `boundsAlignV` within the Text.style object, or can be directly
set through the setters `Text.boundsAlignH` and `Text.boundsAlignV`. Bounds alignment is independent of text alignment.

For example: If your game is 800x600 in size and you set the text bounds to be 0,0,800,600 then by setting boundsAlignH to
'center' and boundsAlignV to 'bottom' the text will render in the center and at the bottom of your game window, regardless of
how many lines of text there may be. Even if you adjust the text content or change the style it will remain at the bottom center
of the text bounds.

This is especially powerful when you need to align text against specific coordinates in your game, but the actual text dimensions
may vary based on font (say for multi-lingual games).

If `Text.wordWrapWidth` is greater than the width of the text bounds it is clamped to match the bounds width.

Call this method with no arguments given to reset an existing textBounds.

It works by calculating the final position based on the Text.canvas size, which is modified as the text is updated. Some fonts
have additional padding around them which you can mitigate by tweaking the Text.padding property. It then adjusts the `pivot`
property based on the given bounds and canvas size. This means if you need to set the pivot property directly in your game then
you either cannot use `setTextBounds` or you must place the Text object inside another DisplayObject on which you set the pivot.

params.description: The x coordinate of the Text Bounds region.
params.name: x

params.description: The y coordinate of the Text Bounds region.
params.name: y

params.description: The width of the Text Bounds region.
params.name: width

params.description: The height of the Text Bounds region.
params.name: height

returns.description: This Text instance.

name: getBounds
description:
Returns the bounds of the Text as a rectangle.
The bounds calculation takes the worldTransform into account.

params.description: The transformation matrix of the Text.
params.name: matrix

returns.description: The framing rectangle

name: purgeGlyphs
description:
If a BitmapText changes from having a large number of characters to having very few characters it will cause lots of
Sprites to be retained in the BitmapText._glyphs array. Although they are not attached to the display list they
still take up memory while sat in the glyphs pool waiting to be re-used in the future.

If you know that the BitmapText will not grow any larger then you can purge out the excess glyphs from the pool
by calling this method.

Calling this doesn't prevent you from increasing the length of the text again in the future.

returns.description: The amount of glyphs removed from the pool.

name: updateOffset
description:
Updates the x and/or y offset that the font is rendered from. This updates all of the texture frames, so be careful how often it is called.
Note that the values given for the x and y properties are either ADDED to or SUBTRACTED from (if negative) the existing offsetX/Y values of the characters.
So if the current offsetY is 8 and you want it to start rendering from y16 you would call updateOffset(0, 8) to add 8 to the current y offset.

Adds value to amount and ensures that the result always stays between 0 and max, by wrapping the value around.

Values _must_ be positive integers, and are passed through Math.abs. See {@link Phaser.Math#wrap} for an alternative.

params.description: The value to add the amount to.
params.name: value

params.description: The amount to add to the value.
params.name: amount

params.description: The maximum the value is allowed to be.
params.name: max

returns.description: The wrapped value.

name: isEven

name: max

Variation of Math.max that can be passed either an array of numbers or the numbers as parameters.

Prefer the standard `Math.max` function when appropriate.

name: minProperty
description:
Variation of Math.min that can be passed a property and either an array of objects or the objects as parameters.
It will find the lowest matching property value from the given objects.

returns.description: The lowest value from those given.

name: maxProperty
description:
Variation of Math.max that can be passed a property and either an array of objects or the objects as parameters.
It will find the largest matching property value from the given objects.

returns.description: The largest value from those given.

name: sinCosGenerator
description:
Generate a sine and cosine table simultaneously and extremely quickly.
The parameters allow you to specify the length, amplitude and frequency of the wave.
This generator is fast enough to be used in real-time.
Code based on research by Franky of scene.at

params.description: The length of the wave
